characters: FOR LANCE CORPORAL ALFRED H. MENDES
KEEP YOUR HEAD DOWN IN DAYLIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rolling landscape. The rustling of leaves, and birdsong Thunder rumbles in the distance. There is no rain. A figure lies against a tree, eyes closed - this is SCHOFIELD, early-20s. Soft features. A man is sleeping next to him on the grass - BLAKE, 19, youthful, strapping.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Blake. Blake doesn’t stir.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Blake! Blake wakes. He’s in uniform, damp and crumpled - Lance Corporal chevrons adorn it.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: (sleepily) Sorry, Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS
dialogues.text: Pick a man, bring your kit.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes, Sarge. Blake stands, stiff limbs coming back to life. Schofield’s eyes are still shut. Blake holds out his hand Schofield. Schofield opens his eyes - they are gentle, wi Schofield grudgingly raises his hand for a lift. Blake heaves him to his feet - his uniform is identical t Blake's, same rank, the only difference is the brass woun stripe on Schofield’s left sleeve. They trudge towards Sanders, fastening their webbing. A smattering of SOLDIERS - same regiment - same state of fatigue and filth, lie around them. Stealing sleep.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t dawdle.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: No, Sarge. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a few paces the long grass begins to give way to we trodden earth. Washing lines appears on either side of th Blake and Schofield move past them. After a while -

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did they feed us? Schofield shakes his head, he hands an envelope to Blake.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No, just mail. Blake’s eyes light up at the sight of the envelope, he te it open, reads it as he walks. Eyes scanning quickly, his face filling with warmth.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: (reading) Myrtle’s having puppies. Blake finishes the note and slips it into a pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You get anything?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No. Schofield doesn’t seem to mind. The mess tents are now alongside. Fires are stoked, cooki is underway. More soldiers mill about.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I'm bloody starving, aren’t you? I thought we might get some decent grub out here - only reason I decided against the priesthood. Schofield lets out a laugh. Blake looks on hungrily as th pass by the mess tents. Schofield rummages in his pockets, finds what he’s lookin for - a handkerchief with some food wrapped in it. Blake’ eyes fall on it hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you got there?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Ham and bread. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Where did you find that?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I have my uses. Schofield breaks the bread in half. As he does this, they move down a slope, and begin to descend down into the ear into-- EXT. COMMS TRENCH —- DAY - CONTINUOUS A narrow Comms trench.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Here- The bread is stale, practically cardboard. Blake’s teeth struggle to get through it.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: (mouth full of food) Tastes like old shoe.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Cheer up. This time next week it’1l be chicken dinner. The trench drops deeper into the earth...

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Not me. Leave got cancelled.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: They say why?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: No idea. A beat. The world above has now disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: It’s easier not to go back at all. Blake registers this - looks at him. The wider Rear Trench crosses their path. Chains of soldi move past them - shifting crates, ammunition, cooking, an medical supplies. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: (looking at the soldiers) Something’s up. Expectation is growing in Blake. But Schofield looks concerned. They cut a route through the bustle.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear anything?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Has to be the push, right? Men carrying things push past them. Blake watches.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ten bob says we’re going up.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I’m not taking that bet.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Why? ‘Cos you know I’m right?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No. ‘Cos you haven’t got ten bob. Blake laughs. They follow Sanders into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn into a wider second line trench.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS
dialogues.text: In your own time, gentlemen... Up ahead, Sanders waits. Blake and Schofield put on speed, catch Sanders.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Is there news, Sarge?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS
dialogues.text: News of what? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: The big push. It was supposed to happen weeks ago. They told us we’d be home by Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS
dialogues.text: (mild sarcasm) Yes, well, sorry to disrupt your crowded schedule, Blake, but the Brass Hats didn’t fancy it in the snow.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: More’s the pity Sarge, I could have done with some turkey.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS
dialogues.text: Well, I’1ll make sure to relay your displeasure to command. Ahead and above them is a web of telegraph wires - stretc overhead and along the trench. THREE ROYAL ENGINEERS are working on them, tagging and testing. They duck around th

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: So what’s on the cards then, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS
dialogues.text: The Hun are up to something.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Any idea what?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS
dialogues.text: No - but it’s bound to ruin our weekend. Sanders turns a corner, and comes to a stop. Just beyond is the dark, yawning mouth of a Dugout.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now listen, Erinmore is inside, so tidy yourselves up. They are suddenly alert.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You never know - might be mentions in dispatches for this one, if you don't bugger it up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders gives them a look, and disappears inside the dugo Schofield quickly buttons up his tunic, hiding any sins t may be underneath. Blake nervously tidies himself, leans in to Schofield.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Must be something big if the General’s here. They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lit by paraffin lamps, it takes Schofield a moment for hi eyes to adjust to the half-light. He and Blake hand their rifles to the ORDERLIES, salute, and stand at attention. There is a simmering sense of unease in this place. In the centre of the room, there are two tables. On one t lie several maps, on the other are a number of large aeri reconnaissance photographs. GENERAL ERINMORE (50s), LIEUTENANT GORDON (40s) and a CAP are gathered around the far table, looking down at the aerials, talking in hushed tones. Other men watch from the shadows - TWO NCOs and ANOTHER ORDERLY.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT SANDERS
dialogues.text: Lance Corporals Blake and Schofield, Sir. General Erinmore turns around. Looks at Blake and Schofie

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ERINMORE
dialogues.text: Which one of you is Blake?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE
dialogues.text: You have a brother, a Lieutenant in the 2nd Devons?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Joseph Blake. Is he- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE
dialogues.text: Alive, as far as I know. And with your help I’d like to keep it that way. Blake stares at Erinmore, he would do anything.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sanders tells me you’re good with Maps. That true?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Good enough, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE
dialogues.text: So. Erinmore turns the map to face Blake. The British lines a marked in blue, the German lines in red.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are here. The 2nd Devons are advancing here. He points out a cross on the map at Croisilles Wood.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long will it take you to get there? Blake hesitantly studies it. Croisilles Wood sits in the centre of a huge area of land, which is scored as occupie territory.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir, that land is held by the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE
dialogues.text: Germans have gone. Shock plays on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t get your hopes up. It appears to be a strategic withdrawal. They seem to have created a new line, nine miles back here, by the looks of it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erinmore runs his finger along the massed red lines of th German trenches and fortifications, newly drawn on the ma The new German Line - what came to be known as the Hinden Line - is huge, and cuts its way across the paper, almost intersecting with Croisilles Wood.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Colonel Mackenzie is in command of the 2nd. He sent word yesterday morning that he was going after the retreating Germans. He is convinced he has them on the run - that if he can break their lines now, he will turn the tide. He is wrong. Schofield watches Blake as he begins to register what thi might mean.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Colonel Mackenzie has not seen these aerials of the enemy’s new line. Erinmore turns to the other table.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come round here, Gentlemen. Blake and Schofield move to the next table. They look dow the large aerial photographs.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three miles deep. Field fortifications, defences and artillery the like of which we've never seen before. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The 2nd are due to attack the line shortly after dawn tomorrow. They have no idea what they are in for. And we can’t warn them - as a parting gift, the enemy cut all our telephone lines. Blake and Schofield are silent while they take this in. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your orders are to get to the 2nd at Croisilles Wood, one mile south east of the town of Ecoust. Erinmore hands over an envelope to Blake. We see the distinctive red stamp of Army Command.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Deliver this to Colonel Mackenzie. It is a direct order to call off tomorrow morning’s attack. Erinmore speaks slowly, desperate to impress upon Blake a Schofield the gravity of this situation. Nothing can be misunderstood.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you don’t, it will be a massacre. We would lose two battalions. Sixteen hundred men, your brother among them. Schofield hides his shock. But Blake looks at Erinmore, determination etched in his face: understood.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think you can get there in time?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE
dialogues.text: Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: No, Sir. Schofield eyes flick to Blake: No questions? Blake purpos doesn’t catch Schofield’s eye.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE
dialogues.text: Good. Over to you, Lieutenant. The men salute Erinmore. Lieutenant Gordon, stands to one side.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GORDON
dialogues.text: Supplies, Gentlemen. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lt. Gordon nods them over to a table. Various items are l out on it.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GORDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Map, torches, grenades, and a couple of little treats. They look. A folded map, two electric torches, two grenad and two small packs of Huntley and Palmer biscuits lie on table. They take them and start hastily putting them into their webbing. While they do:

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GORDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave immediately, take this trench west, up on Sauchiehall Street, then north west on Paradise Alley at the front. Continue along the front line until you find the Yorks. Gordon slides a note into Blake’s top pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GORDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give this note to Major Stevenson. He’s holding the line at the shortest span of No Man’s Land. You'll cross there. Both men turn at the mention of No Man’s Land.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: It will be daylight, Sir. They’1l see us.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: No need to be concerned. You should meet no resistance. An Orderly hands them back their rifles. Blake moves towards the doorway. Schofield turns to Erinm

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir, is it just us? Erinmore looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE
dialogues.text: “Down to Gehenna or up to the Throne (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He travels the fastest who travels alone." Wouldn't you say, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GORDON
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. I would. The General looks at them levelly.

dialogues.speaker: ERINMORE
dialogues.text: Good luck. Blake and Schofield turn and head through the door-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield’s eyes wince in the daylight. A small curved br leads from the rear of the dugout back to the Second Line

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Blake - let’s talk about this for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Why? Blake is already off, moving fast. Schofield moves after him, trying to fill and fasten his webbing as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Blake! Blake begins to move faster, setting a punishing pace. Bo clattering over the wooden boards.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We just need to think about it-

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: -There’s nothing to think about. It’s my big brother. Schofield runs to catch up, he falls in behind Blake, breathing heavy.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: We should at least wait till it’s dark- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second cottages. collect th Schofield 12.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Erinmore said to leave immediately.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Erinmore’s never seen No Man's Land. We won’t make it ten yards. If we just wait-

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: You heard him. He said the Boche have gone.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Is that why he gave us grenades? line runs through a small row of derelict railway Braziers have been lit, men mill around queueing to eir rations. and Blake push themselves to the edge of the trench to get around the crush. Blake is through and clear, but Schofield bumps into a Sergeant. Blake keep;

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Watch where you’re going!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sorry. s pace, Schofield jogs to catch him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is that we wait.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes, you would say that, because it’s not your brother, is it? Schofield moves alongside Blake again, grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Look, the last time I was told the Germans were gone, it didn’t end well. Blake shakes him off, and pushes his way forward, squeezi in and out of the lines of traffic - His shoulder and pack battering against MEN as he passes them. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t know, Blake, you weren’t there. Ahead a group of men are bunched up collecting mail and parcels from the post bag. Gumming up the trench.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Excuse me! Blake and Schofield squeeze past them. Another junction. A painted sign: “SAUCHIEHALL STREET” po to a smaller branching comms line. Blake turns up it. Schofield follows- EXT. SAUCHIEHALL LINE (COMMS “DOWN” TRENCH)- CONTINUOUS Much narrower. Blake pushes onwards, going against the direction of the traffic. Schofield follows after him, si file, increasingly frustrated. Soldiers buffet against th A Sergeant snarls at them.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT MILLER
dialogues.text: You're going up a down trench you bloody idiots.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Orders of the General, Sir. Schofield follows, catching the ire from the men Blake ha just passed. He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Alright, say the Boche have gone. Nine miles will take us, what, six hours? Eight at the very most. So we've got time to wait until the sun sets. Otherwise we'll be wide open-

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: -It’s enemy territory, we’ve got no idea what we’re walking into-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: -Blake, if we're not clever about this, no one will get to your brother. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I will. Blake’s tone indicates that this is the end of the conversation. They are approaching a junction. They slow down. A flicke fear on both of their faces.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: We're here. This is the front line. EXT. PARADISE (FRONT LINE) TRENCH —- CONTINUOUS The Front Line. A sign hangs on the junction wall: PARADISE ALLEY. Just visible above the trench wall to the front is an endless of wire.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Now we need to find the Yorks. There is an eeriness here, a sudden smothering silence. Blake looks around. Trying to work out which way is North West. Blake heads in that direction, moving fast again. Schofie follows alongside him. The trench stretches away from them, in a long line. Duckboards slick with mud mark out a path. There are many men here, and many pairs of eyes watch fro the shadows of dugouts. Crudely painted signs are strung up along the walls, dire warnings. We catch glimpses as Blake and Schofield pass:

dialogues.speaker: KEEP YOUR HEAD DOWN IN DAYLIGHT
dialogues.text: They walk single file down the Front Line. TWO STRETCHER BEARERS are heading towards them, A MAN car between them. Schofield drops back, looks down. The man i unconscious, his face bandaged - two red bloodstains in p of eyes. Fear is rooting itself in Schofield. He fights it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Schofield looks up, he’s briefly lost sight of Blake roun the next bend. He moves to catch up. He hears voices.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE STOKES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Here, watch who you’re shoving.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get out of the way then. Schofield’s puts on speed, quickly pushes aside the soldi in front of him. He makes his way to Blake, three SOLDIERS have surrounded him. One, PRIVATE STOKES - a large red-haired bruiser, wi tattoos on his forearms - is gripping Blake’s tunic. Blak has him by the collar. Both are angry. Blake is on the ve of tears.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let go.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE STOKES
dialogues.text: Fuck you think you are, pushing wounded men around? Schofield is quickly into the fray, putting himself in between Blake and the Private.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Let go of me!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE STOKES
dialogues.text: Arsehole knocked our Sergeant down, the man’s fucking wounded- Beside them an NCO with a sling on, is being helped out o the mud.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Alright. I’m sorry, alright, I’m sorry. Blake struggles to get free, tears of frustration well in eyes. Schofield sees this, realises Blake is on the verge losing control. The Private’s hand balls into a fist, his anger simmering Schofield gets between them. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: We’re on commission. Orders from the General.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Let me through. Stokes stops.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (levelly) Get out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE STOKES
dialogues.text: Right. Just watch where you’re going. The other men move aside to give them a passage through. They keep moving. Schofield is a step behind Blake, he st glances at him, concerned. The two men walk on, the silence heavier. After a while -

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: It’s bloody quiet... A beat. Blake looks at Schofield.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Was it like this before Thiepval? The name does something to Schofield. Fear clings to him. pushes it away.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: You don’t remember the Somme?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Well, you did alright out of it. At least wear your ribbon. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Don’t have it anymore. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They push on round the next bend.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What? You lost your medal? Before he can answer, the trench suddenly expands - the b wall has been blown out into a large crater. Debris and sandbags are strewn around. A small team of DIGGERS work it with picks and shovels, breaking up the earth, pulling body parts from the mud, putting them in empty sandbags.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Stay low. Schofield climbs over the rubble and sandbags, crushing h body to keep his head below the front parapet. Blake follows. One of the diggers turns to Schofield, his voice a harsh whisper.

dialogues.speaker: NCO HARVEY
dialogues.text: God's sake. Careful there, you’re stepping on the dead. Schofield looks at the sandbag, 15 inches by 25. Red is rusting through it.

dialogues.speaker: NCO HARVEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s our Sergeant - Schofield quickly moves off the bag.

dialogues.speaker: NCO HARVEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be better washing them out of this dugout with a bloody hose.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Do you know where the Yorks are?

dialogues.speaker: NCO HARVEY
dialogues.text: The next bend you’1l be standing on top of half of them. Shot to hell two nights ago. Blake and Schofield continue. They slip round a bend and a small bay. They stop by two men - one is burning the lice from his clothes with a lighter Another, BUCHANAN, sits against th back wall, a small dog on his lap. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Yorks? Buchanan nods.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Corp.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Where’s Major Stevenson?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Killed a couple of nights ago, Corporal. Lieutenant Leslie has command.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Where can we find him? Buchanan nods down the line.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: Next dug-out. They round the bend and spot the dugout. It has been badl shelled, but patched and re-built. A fire is lit in a bra just outside the door. Inside, a provisions bag and a few other wooden items hang from a rafter, out of reach of th rats.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Here. LT. LESLIE is asleep on a small camp bed, his arm over hi eyes. A couple of ORDERLIES sit or lie nearby. They approach the sleeping Leslie.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Sir? He doesn’t stir. Blake speaks louder.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Leslie, Sir? Leslie stirs a little, he doesn’t move his arm from his e

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: What is it? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: We have a message from General Erinmore. Leslie looks up, his face shines with sweat, his voice is croaky, full of flu, a little delirious.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: Are you our relief? Schofield shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: Then when the fucking hell are they due?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: We don’t know, Sir. But we’ve got orders to cross here. Blake offers the letter. Leslie sits up. Looks at them queerly.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: That is the German front line.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: We know, Sir. If you'll just take the letter- Blake hands over Erinmore’s letter. Leslie sighs, tears i open and reads quickly.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: (as he reads) Settle a bet, what day is it?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Friday.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: Friday. Well, well, well. None of us was right. This idiot thought it was Tuesday. (off the letter) Are they out of their fucking minds? (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One slow night, and the brass think the Hun have just gone home.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (looking at Blake) Do you think they’re wrong, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: We lost an officer and three men two nights ago. They were shot to bits patching up wire. We dragged two of them back here. Needn’t have bothered. Blake is determined to press on.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Sir, the General is sure the enemy have withdrawn. There are aerials of the new line- Leslie gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: Shut up. We’ve fought and died over every inch of this fucking place, now they suddenly give us miles? Schofield turns and stares at Blake. Blake won’t meet his eye.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a trap. Leslie leans in to Schofield.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But, chin up. There’s a medal in it for sure. Nothing like a scrap of ribbon to cheer up a widow. Schofield stares at him like he would lift him out of his boots with one punch.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright. Leslie walks out of the dugout. As he walks- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Where’s the nearest way through, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: Our wire’s a mess. But there is a path through. Of sorts. He leads them a few paces to a small dead-end lookout tre half earth, half corrugated steel. At the end of it isa rudimentary periscope.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the soldier) Rushworth! Let him look. The soldier manning it steps away to allow them to look. Blake presses his eye to the lens.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Straight ahead, to the left, past the dead horses- Blake squints, moves the periscope. While Blake does this Leslie lights a cigarette, his hands shaking.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a gap directly behind them. Useful, because if it’s dark you follow the stench. When you get to the second wire, look out for the bowing chap. There’s small break just beside him. As Blake scans the terrain with the periscope, Schofield methodically prepares himself.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The German line is a hundred and fifty odd yards after that. Watch out for the craters. They’re deeper than they look. You fall in, there’s no getting out. Leslie indicates for them to follow.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This way. Leslie kicks at a sleeping PRIVATE KILGOUR as he walks. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wake up, Kilgour. (to himself) Bloody waste of space.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Any cover, Sir? Anywhere to jump off from? Leslie leads them to a wide ladder leaning against the tr wall.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: No. The sap trench was blown to hell weeks ago. It’s full of bodies anyway. Your best bet is to pop over here. Blake and Schofield stop by the ladder, ready themselves, checking and loading their rifles, fixing their bayonets

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you do get shot, try to make it back to the wire. We won’t come after you, not until it’s dark. And, if by some fucking miracle you do make it, send up a flare.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Don’t have any, Sir. Leslie gestures impatiently to a nearby PRIVATE KILGOUR.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: Well get him one, Kilgour! Make yourself useful.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE KILGOUR
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. Kilgour goes to fetch the flare gun, Leslie amuses himsel

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE
dialogues.text: (sprinkling whisky on the men) “Through this holy unction may the Lord pardon thee whatever sins or faults thou hast committed” Leslie laughs mirthlessly. Schofield and Blake try to sta focused. Kilgour hands Leslie a flare pistol and two cartridges. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do hate losing these to the Hun. So when they start shooting at you, could you be so kind as to throw it back, there’s a good chap. Blake tucks the flare and cartridges into his pack.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cheerio. Leslie steps back. A crowd of MEN have now gathered behin him to watch Blake and Schofield, their faces a combinati of shock and fascination. Blake and Schofield climb onto the firing step. Schofield looks at Blake, speaks quietly to him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: You sure? Blake isn’t. But he nods.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes. Blake goes to climb over. Schofield stops him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Age before beauty. Schofield takes a deep breath, and goes first. He puts on hand over the parapet. Then the other. Slowly he advances up, his head inching over the protecti of the trench. His hand is shaking, he drives it into the mud, grasping for purchase. Everyone is still, breathless, listening for the enemy to fire. Schofield drags his body up and over into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vast, almost unbearably open after the close quarters of trench. A light mist hangs low over the land. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The ground is treacle-like. Schofield’s hands and knees s into it as he pulls himself forward, his eyes are trained through the British wire towards the German lines. The whole world is lunar and empty. Earth pounded to atom all mounds and holes. Nothing moves. Nothing lives. The only sound is Blake’s breathing as he heaves himself of the trench beside Schofield. Both men are still for a beat. Hunched down low on their knees, two nocturnal animals caught in the daylight. British wire runs in loops ahead of them, tangled and haphazardly strung. A mess to navigate through. They get to their feet and move forwards over the slick earth, towards the putrid remains of the horses. Breathin through their mouths, trying to deal with the stench. A layer of black fur covers the animals, as Schofield and Blake close in on them they see the fur is actually flies hundreds of them. Schofield moves past the remains and through the first br in the wire. The path is pocked with craters and puddles, shrapnel litters everything. Blake follows Schofield through the channel - ahead, on t second wire, is “the bowing chap” - a GERMAN SOLDIER, dea bent double over the wire, one arm outstretched in a cour manner, as if bowing. Schofield doesn’t linger on the dead German, doesn’t look his face. He focuses on the task at hand. To the side of man is a small gap in the razor wire, easy to miss withou the landmark. Schofield struggles to further pull apart t dense tangle of wire. He indicates for Blake to pass thro As he does so, Schofield slips in the mud. His hand instinctively closes around the wire. It slices into his palm, hooking into his flesh. Bright red seeps along his hand, he wrenches it back, tea the skin to free himself. A heavy breath hisses out of hi He balls his hand into a fist to stem the bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You alright? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake looks at him with concern. Schofield nods that he’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Look for cover. Everything after here is unnatural land. Craters are goug out of the earth. There is a rise and fall to this stretc but no flow or reason to it. About a hundred yards from them, in the distance, is an artificial horizon, something grey, mesh-like, stretching entire length of the land - The German Wire. Occasional d trees dot the land beyond. Blake goes into the closest crater. He looks to Schofield some silent communication. Schofield’s eyes pull out a pa where there isn’t one.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sap trench. Schofield goes first, crouching low, moving faster now, picking his way towards a hole in the earth. And then jumps directly into the old sap trench. Blown out and neglected, it is now little more than a dit but it offers a stretch of cover. Schofield checks his wounded hand. It pulses blood. He fe as if he is being watched. He looks around. Next to him is the body of a German soldier; face down in mud, rats are on the corpse, feasting. Blake jumps into the sap just next to Schofield. He lands right next to A DEAD MAN, looking straight at them. He is sitting up, his lips and eyes have been chewed off by rat White teeth grin in a pale face. Blake reflexively scrambles back in horror, knocking into Schofield. Schofield slips, reaches out to steady himself and grabs at the first thing he finds - the BODY OF THE GERMAN. Schofield’s wounded hand lands on the man’s back and sink right through. Schofield’s cut hand goes into the putrid flesh. Beside him, Blake is frozen. Panicking. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Schofield gestures to him - ‘stay calm’. Blake tries to steady himself. They move further along the side of the sap trench. Schof peers out. About eighty yards now to the German wire. They gather themselves. Schofield takes the lead. He pull himself out of the sap, Blake follows. They move, crouched low. Watching. Waiting for guns to op on them. Silence. The land is flatter here. There is an eerie feeling of emptiness and silence. Schofield and Blake keep moving forwards, trying to stay focused. Crouching to keep low. The mud is like oil, but some things are solid underfoot. Outlines of guns, shrapnel, unexploded shells, bodies. Suddenly a loud sound approaching. TWO PLANES. Blake and Schofield both move quickly to the nearest shel hole. They throw themselves in and freeze. Keeping the br of their helmets low, hiding their faces from the planes above. Blending in to the landscape around them.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Sotto) Stay still. The engines grow louder. The planes fly close overhead, a then begin to recede into the distance. Both men now turn their heads to look at them.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Sotto) They’re ours. Blake nods.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Sotto) Keep going. We’re half way. They move back out into the open expanse. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Large shell holes appear on either side of them. They pic their way through them, balancing carefully along the rid They climb to the top of a small hillock and suddenly on other-side - vertigo. The ground falls away steeply in a crater, stories deep. They look down into it.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: There’s a gap in the wire. We can see the base of the crater: The nearest line of Ge wire has been split by the blast, and hangs limply down t side wall of the crater, the other half of it disappears a huge pool of water at its base. They meet each other’s gaze. An obvious way through the w It’s clear they need to go down into the crater. They slide carefully down the steep bank. At the base of the crater the water is fathomless - the colour of mucus, and the same consistency. A DEAD GERMAN floats in it, bloated. Blake follows in Schofield’s exact footsteps, walking aro the edge of the pool. Blake looks into the pool. Things float in it. Bodies. Th pages of a letter, a cigarette tin, a water canteen. Ahead of them, halfway up the far bank another line of Ge wire - the main one - is suspended across the crater. The is a gap beneath the wire. They climb up the far bank towards the gap. Blake is struggling.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sco... Schofield helps him up the slope. The main German wire is a huge thicket of razor wire, den than a hedgerow. Using their hands, they dig into the mud sides of the crater, and pull themselves upwards, through German wire. Schofield looks - close to him, caught on the wire, a sma clump of human hair blows in the breeze. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hands and bayonets digging deep into the muddy bank, they haul themselves out of the crater. Ahead of them is the German Front Line.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There! That’s the front line. They lift their rifles and aim them towards the German li Blake moves first. He quickly approaches the German trenc Schofield is next to him. Both men suck in a breath and stand tall, leaning over th German sandbags. Their rifles sweep in unison down the length of the trenc Empty. Schofield turns to Blake.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck me. They really have gone. They look around in awe - this trench is massive, fortified... and seemingly abandoned. Intermittent shell holes have levelled large sections. Blake and Schofield drop down into the trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This trench is better crafted than the British trench. De and well reinforced, and eerily empty. They are alone. To one side the trench is smashed in. A mountain of earth debris. Blocked. Schofield crouches, attends to his bleeding hand. Blood o out of it.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Your hand alright?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Put it through an effing German. Schofield has taken out his canteen, he pours water on hi sliced up palm. Blake keeps watch.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Patch it up. You’ll be wanking again in no time. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Wrong hand. Blake laughs. Blake moves off, rifle ready. Schofield follows, wrapping bandage round his hand as they move. He tightens the dres with his teeth. Red seeps through the white gauze. Ahead of them is a brazier, full of spent white coal dust Blake kicks it over, the white dust crumbles, red embers - wisps of smoke. Still smouldering. Schofield turns to Blake, his eyes are on the embers too.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re not long gone. Blake hands tighten on his rifle, he pushes off, heading down-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake leads them into the deep, narrow trench. Creeping forward quickly, eyes darting ahead, looking for any enem The comms trench opens out into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake hovers by the mouth of the comms trench, peeking ou Another dead end.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: No good. Schofield is at his back. Their eyes scan the empty secon line trench. They push on in silence. Their footsteps click and echo over the duckboards. They move, bayonets pointed forward. The trench takes a sharp turn. Schofield and Blake inch round, rifles up, checking. Ahead of them the trench is destroyed. A direct hit. Eart sandbags, and huge splinters of timber jut out of the pil dirt. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Blocked. It is impassable. Next to them is the mouth of a dugout. A doorway. Blake peers into the darkness. Timber stairs descend two storeys down into the earth.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: This might be a way through. They click on their torches and move down the stairs. Whole tree trunks have been used to reinforce the walls. share a look. The sophistication of the Germans amazes th At the foot of the steps, Blake turns the corner.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jesus... Schofield follows him quickly, the timber creaks under hi he rounds into the mouth of-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the corner and sees Blake, torch in hand.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Look at this. It’s massive. The dugout is huge - an entire barracks carved out of the chalky earth. It’s ghostly in the torch light. Timber struts run along walls and ceilings. Rows of bunk run along the length of the huge room, stacked up to the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They built all this. Blake and Schofield move through it, their torchlights slicing through the darkness. It is palatial compared wit what we have seen on the British lines. Schofield’s eyes land on something - a photograph, someon wife and child, pinned to a bed frame. Schofield stares a for a beat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake noses through some of the detritus left behind by t Germans, then moves through into: The Officer’s Quarters: Iron bed frames, an arm chair, a desk. In one corner are the remains of a cooking area, so boxes of supplies lie abandoned. Next to one of the beds a tunnel stretches away from him the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Here’s our way through.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Sco - how about this? Schofield turns to see Blake sitting on one of the office beds, bouncing gently. The springs squeak loudly in the silence, he grins. Then movement catches his eye. A massi rat gnaws on a canvass sack suspended form the roof beams

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bloody hell... Even their rats are bigger than ours. By the light of their torches, they can see a large, bloa rat moving quickly along one of the roof beams. Their torches follow the rat, as it scampers along the be The light catches more canvas sacks, all suspended from a ceiling. Grease is pooling at the base of them, turning t translucent - bags of food, or at least an approximation it. Other frayed and empty canvas sacks lie around.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think’s in the bags?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: You cannot be that hungry. Blake thinks for a beat. The rat makes a leap for one, dropping from the rafter to canvas. The bag swings violently under the rat’s weight, pendulum in the middle of the room.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Look at him. Cocky little bastard. Something has caught Schofield’s eye. A crate full of foo tins has been left in the corner. Schofield walks over an grabs one. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: You could eat this, though. He turns to read the writing in Blake’s torch light: “Fleischkonserve”

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What is it? Schofield tosses a tin across the room to him. Blake catc it, reads the label.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Boche dog meat.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What’s in the other boxes? Schofield goes for the other crate... and freezes.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Trip wire. Blake stands stock still.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t move. The two men are frozen.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Goes from here to the door. Blake’s breath quickens as he scans the room, trying to p out the wire in the torchlight... The door is about ten f away. Suddenly -

dialogues.speaker: BAM
dialogues.text: Both men jump - The rat and the canvas bag are on the flo

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Jesus! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The rat is dragging the canvas bag towards the door to th next room, desperate to keep its treasure from the two me

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No...no! —- Blake's eyes go wide, he starts forward for the rat- The rat lets go of the bag and flees - into the wire. A f of blinding light then almost simultaneously-

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: Impossibly loud. The blast is reflected back in off the s walls, a section of roof drops. Dirt and chalk dust blast outward. Blake is flung backwards against the wall with a thud. White chalk dust swirls in the room, bright in the torchlight. Blake’s torch lands on the floor, beam pointi upwards at the ceiling. For a second there is silence. Blake begins to pant. The wind is knocked out of him. He catches his breath. He feels his head, reaches for his torch. His eyes scan t room. His torchlight slices through the dust and smoke. The wor has been turned over. Some parts are buried. And where Schofield was standing - a pile of rubble. Panic streaks across his face. Then there is a sound. Muffled, from deep in the white di Screaming. Schofield is buried. Blake is on his feet, staggering towards the mound of cha and dust. Moving over it, ears to the dirt, listening. Schofield’s screams slip through it. Blake frantically begins to dig.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sco?! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ripping earth away from one spot, then listening to Schofield’s muffled screams and moving to another. Desperation on his face.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: sco! The screams are getting weaker. Disappearing beneath the sounds of the timber creaking and groaning. Blake swims through the earth, sweeping it away- Schofield’s screams stop. Blake thrashes in the chalk - at last unearths - Lips. Schofield’s mouth, wide open, filled with pale grey dirt. Still.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: sco! sco! Blake tears the chalk away from his mouth and nose and suddenly Schofield heaves into life, retches, coughing up dirt, sawing in breaths. Blake uncovers Schofield’s face, his eyes are packed with dirt and chalk. Blake keeps digging, frees Schofield’s ar chest. Schofield thrashes in the debris, trying to free himself. He can’t. It’s too tightly packed.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sco! Wake up! Wake up! Sco! Blake grabs at Schofield’s arm and with all his might wrenches him out of the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sco... Stand up! Stand up! Up! UP! Schofield is in shock - numb. Caked in the pale white ear His heaves and retches fill the tiny space. His body shak and contorting with shock.

dialogues.speaker: STAND UP
dialogues.text: The timber is groaning all around them now. Blake looks u it.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The whole thing’s coming down. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Blake looks, the chalk dust swirls in the air, drawn towards the tunnel entrance, sucked out by the backdraft. Their way out. Blake stands, half-drags Schofield to his feet. Schofield hardly see out of his dust-filled eyes. Blake pulls him o to the tunnel entrance.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You keep hold of me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carved through the chalk bedrock. Seven feet high and reinforced with timber, some of which have already split the blast. The tunnel slopes gently down, deeper into the earth. White walls reflect Blake’s torch. The earth around them groans, silt and dust piss from the ceiling. Schofield coughs and convulses, grasping on to Blake, tow along in his wake. The tunnel splits, one fork has been destroyed, Blake pul them forward the only way they can go.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: We need to keep moving. Come on!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I can’t see - I can’t see! Blake stops suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop! He has kicked a bucket that sits on the lip of a mineshaf The bucket drops into the hole, pulleys spinning ferociou

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop. It’s a mineshaft. Blake looks for a way round it. It has been blown by the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll have to jump. Come on! Blake jumps across it. Schofield is frozen. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to have to jump! Just jump.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I can’t- I can’t see! Blake wheels around and shines his light on Schofield. Schofield’s eyes stream with tears and debris, he’s paralyzed, blinded. Between them is nothing but a gaping hole in the floor, fathomless blackness. The walls around them groan under the strain. The place i coming down.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: You need to trust me. Jump! Schofield tears in a breath then leaps forwards towards Blake. Schofield takes off, jumps across the hole and lands hard His back foot slips down the side of the mineshaft, but B grabs him, and heaves him up. Blake pushes forward, Schofield clings to him.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t let go of me! Don’t let go! The sound of earth collapsing suddenly fills the tunnel. dugout behind them has collapsed in. Ahead there is a fork in the tunnel. Blake spots somethin his right - a blue haze. Daylight. He pulls Schofield towards it.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Light! There’s light! They scramble forwards. Light begins to flood the passage way. They reach the end of the tunnel and stumble out int the light.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake scrambles down a small incline, scanning for enemy. They are in a large sunken ditch. Schofield stands, bent double, at the mouth of the tunnel trying to catch his breath. Both of them are covered with chalk dust. They look like pale ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Stop... stop. Just...just let me stand.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Dirty bastards. Schofield gathers himself and drops down beside Blake. Blake pushes on, climbing up a small rise, rifle ready. Schofield goes after him, shakily.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Careful, they may have left other traps. Blake crests the small berm and looks. Curving away from him - a quarry. A huge desolate amphitheatre. The quarry is several storeys high. Holes and entrances a carved all over it, like rabbit warrens. Scattered around is the detritus of war. Several huge Ger guns and some small artillery lie damaged and abandoned. Small mountains of brass - thousands of spent shell casin

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. Blake sweeps his rifle around, searching for any threat. place is abandoned. Schofield makes it to the top of the berm, and drops down the ground, trying to clean out his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Dust... so much dust in my eyes. He empties the remaining water from his canteen onto his face. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake approaches Schofield, hands him his canteen. Schofi washes the chalk off of his face.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Here. Have some of mine. Blake crouches beside him. He watches him, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish I’d shot that rat now. Schofield turns on him, sharp.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: And I wish you'd picked some other bloody idiot.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Why in God’s name did you have to choose me? Schofield checks his pockets - takes out small tobacco ti Checks inside it. His hands are shaking badly.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know what I was picking you for.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No, you didn’t. You never know. That’s your problem. Blake is stung.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Alright then, go back. Nothing’s stopping you. You can go all the way bloody home if you want. At the mention of home Schofield turns on him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Don’t. A beat. Schofield puts the tobacco tin back in his pocket (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: (calmer now) Look, I didn’t know what I was picking you for. I thought they were going to send us back up the line, or for food, or something. I thought it was going to be something easy, alright? I never thought it would be this. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So do you want to go back? Schofield looks at him, softening.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Just fire the fucking flare. He loads and lifts the flare, and looks back towards the British lines.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Up yours, Lieutenant... He fires it straight up. The light streaks through the sk He watches it drop. Blake tosses the flare gun, lowers his hand to Schofield helps him up. Schofield stands unsteadily. Blake studies his compass, getting his bearing.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Do you know where we are?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Ecoust is directly south east. If we keep that bearing, we should make it. He looks in the direction Blake is facing - the land roll gently down, a trampled road leads out of the quarry, a shattered copse of trees juts out of the earth. Charred a black. Schofield nods. Blake stows the compass. Raises his rifle (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on then. They begin to walk. Blankets, ammunition, guns, bayonets, shells. All have be abandoned in this place. They pass the remains of artille the gun barrels have been blown out.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at that. They destroyed their own guns...

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: They destroyed their own trenches too.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I think they wanted us to go that way. They wanted to bury us. They walk. A noise startles them both. They turn to the source, read fire - A large rat scuttles over A DEAD GERMAN. Blake kicks a ro at it. It scatters.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Bastard rats. Blake looks across at Schofield. He is still shaking slightly. They walk, watchful. Eventually:

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey - did you hear that story about Wilko? How he lost his ear?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I’m not in the mood. Keep your eyes on the trees, top of the ridge. Blake watches the top of the slope. They walk.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Bet he told you it was shrapnel. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: What was it then?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Well, you know his girl’s a hairdresser, right? And he was moaning about the lack of bathing facilities when he wrote to her - remember those rancid jakes at Arras? Schofield nods - they were disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, she sends him over this ‘hair oil’. Smells sweet, like Golden Syrup. Wilko loves the smell, but he doesn’t want to cart it around in his pack, so- They continue into the-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tread carefully over the battered earth. It’s littered with casings and flecks of metal.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: He slathers it all over his barnet, goes to sleep and in the middle of the night he wakes up, and a rat is sitting on his shoulder licking the oil off of his head! Schofield begins to laugh, despite himself.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wilko panics and he jumps up and when he does - the rat bites clean through his fucking ear and runs off with it! They are both laughing quietly.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, he made a hell of a fuss, yelling, screaming. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The ground sweeps gently downward out of the burnt copse. Living things return to the world in small patches.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best of it was he put so much bloody oil on himself that he couldn’t wash it off! He was like a Magnet. Rats left us alone, but they couldn’t get enough of him. Poor bastard. They emerge from the copse, scanning the surroundings. Th appear to be alone. Above, far in the distance, the same two British planes s to hover in the sky, arcing back towards British lines. Schofield looks up at them.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Heading back home. (beat) I wonder what they saw... Schofield pulls his eyes away from the planes. The two me briefly scan the land around them.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Watch the ridge lines. They move off again. Blake’s eyes stick to the left, Schofield’s scan the right. After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Well that’s your medal sorted then.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? They continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: “Lance Corporal Blake showed unusual valour in rescuing a comrade from certain death” blah, blah, blah.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: You reckon?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I do. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake is pleased.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Well, that’d be nice. Since you lost yours. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I didn’t lose mine. Schofield keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What happened to it, then?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Why do you care?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Why do you not? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I swapped it with a French captain.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Swapped it? For what?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What did you do that for?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I was thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: What a waste. (beat) You should have taken it home with you, you should have given it to your family. Schofield doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Men have died for that. No response. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I got a medal, I'd take it back home, why didn’t you just take it home-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Look it’s just a bit of bloody tin! It doesn’t make you special, it doesn’t make any difference to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes it does. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And it’s not just a bit of tin. (then) It’s got a ribbon on it. Schofield laughs, exasperated. Then he turns to Blake, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I hated going home. I hated it. When I knew I couldn’t stay. When I knew I had to leave them, and they might never see me- He chokes up. Fights with himself for a moment. Then he t and walks ahead. Blake watches him, feeling guilty. Then he follows. Up ahead, Schofield is approaching the remains of a walle orchard. He stops at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The near wall has partially collapsed in a mound of rubbl Beyond it cherry trees litter the ground. All have been c down, felled in the wanton destruction of the German retr Pale blossoms swim all around, ruffled by the wind. Schofield looks at it all.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (to himself) Jesus. They chopped them all down. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake has followed him, a little guiltily. Wanting to apologise, but unsure how. He takes in the orchard.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Cherries. Blake looks at one of the trees. He reaches down, picks a blossom, holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lamberts. They begin to walk through the felled trees.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They might be Dukes, hard to tell when they aren’t in fruit.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: What’s the difference? Blake is a little wry, sensing Schofield softening.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Well people think there’s one type, but there’s lots of them - Cuthberts, Queen Annes, Montmorencys. Sweet ones, sour ones...

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Why on earth would you know this?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Mum’s got an orchard, back home. Only a few trees. This time of year it looks like it’s been snowing, blossom everywhere. And then in May, we have to pick them. Me and Joe. Takes the whole day. A pang of homesickness creeps into Blake as he and Schofi clamber over a downed tree. They are now alongside each other. Schofield registers this.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: So, these ones all gonners? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Oh no, they’1l grow again when the stones rot. You’1ll end up with more trees than before. A large wall borders the lower end of the orchard, still intact. Schofield arrives at the gate. Ahead of them, visible through the gate is a small valley the valley lie the remains of a French farmhouse, abandon It is utterly derelict now - the roof is just a skeleton beams. Next to it is a clapboard barn, ragged with shell holes. Schofield and Blake peer through the gate at the small collection of buildings below. Everything is still. Schofield looks anxiously at the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It looks abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Let’s hope so.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: We have to make sure. Schofield leads the way, he moves through the gate cautiously, rifle raised. Blake follows. They slip down the hill. They are in an old pigsty, surrounded by a broken fence, which runs down to the murk water of a pond. Carefully, as he walks, Schofield scans the buildings ahe The wind rustles the long grass. An ominous atmosphere pervades this place. They approach the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (sotto) I’ll take front, you take back. They split. Blake disappears round the back, Schofield mo towards the front door. A DEAD DOG lies by the path. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Schofield looks at it for a beat. His hands tighten on hi rifle, as he braces himself for what might be inside. Schofield quickly walks up the small front path, through open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is still for a moment on the threshold, breath held, listening for any sounds of life in the house. The silence burns. Schofield enters. The only sounds now are the floor board creaking under his boots. This place has been trashed by the soldiers who were here Schofield turns right into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield moves through the bedroom. Empty. He moves back into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield crosses the hallway. He spots Blake through the window.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Nothing. Schofield moves forward towards the kitchen. Something catches his eye. A child’s doll sits on the floor. Cigarette burns on its eyes. Schofield looks at it for a beat. Then moves into the kitchen.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low, dusty light streaks in from the smashed windows. Schofield takes in the room. Blake enters through the bac door.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Did you find any food?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No. (beat) I don’t like this place. He moves out through the back door-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield moves across the barren yard to a dilapidated b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remnants and debris are scattered around. The low sounds of a cow echo from the fields beyond. Schofield looks - a single COW stands in the field. Two o three other dead cows lie near it. Schofield turns, scanning the barn floor. He peers into a milk urn, it’s empty. Close by there is a bucket, lid half on. He tips the lid off with his foot - Milk. He kneels and smells it, then lowers in a hand and lifts to his mouth. It’s been months since he tasted anything a good. Behind him, Blake exits the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Map says we get over that ridge and it’s a straight shot to Ecoust.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Good. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes out his empty canteen and pours milk into it, fi it to the brim. The huge door at back of the barn is open to the fields. The drone of plane engines through the doorway catches Schofield’s attention. Schofield spots planes through the barn door. He moves towards them to get a better look. Entranced. He moves outside to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield wanders out away from the barn. He looks up int the grey sky. Three planes - a dogfight. Tiny at this distance, insect- like. Schofield’s eyes follow them keenly: Two British fighters against one German. The violence is so far removed from him that it looks balletic. Beautiful even. He moves towards them to get a better look. The planes twist and circle in the air, engines droning a whining as the planes dip and rise.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that our friends again?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Looks like it. Dogfight.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Who's winning?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Us, I think. Two on one. The two of them stand looking up at the majesty of it. Then, in the distance, the German plane begins to trail b smoke. The hum of the German engine fails. The two British plane follow it, hammering away on their guns until it is clear that there is no hope for the German. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: They got him... The German plane coasts silently towards the earth. Blake and Schofield watch as it gets closer and closer. Hypnotised. From the bend of wings you can tell the PILOT is trying t glide. Trying and failing. The plane drops like a leaf, catching updrafts only to suddenly dip again - aiming for the fields some distance ahead of them. The plane dips. Wobbles. Fighting to stay up. It banks le and drops below the horizon. Schofield walks forwards to have a better look. Then suddenly, the plane reappears over the horizon, flying ve low. It is heading straight at them. Schofield realises they are in the path of the plane. He begins backing away, retreating towards the house. The plane is much closer now, behind them as they run. Th can’t make it back to the house. Schofield and Blake throw themselves down on the ground, pressing themselves into the earth as the plane screams i their direction, smashing into the barn directly behind t Black smoke pours from the plane and the shattered skelet of the barn. The fire is quick, licking along the old wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke billows from the plane. Inside it someone is scream Blake moves first, he runs into the barn, Schofield taili him. Tongues of fire whip out from the engine, the pilot is inside. Burning. Flames lick at his mangled legs and torso, his gloved han cover his face. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake grabs at the man, the back of his hand touches the as he tries to free the pilot - he cries out as the metal sears his skin. Schofield tears open the pilot’s strap and together they wrench him free, dragging him from the remains of the cockpit, and pulling his body through the smoke. The Pilot’s legs are on fire.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT PILOT
dialogues.text: Meine beine! Meine beine! My legs! My legs! Help me! Hilf mir! Hilf mir! Help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield and Blake drag the pilot by his shoulders - the true extent of his injuries laid bare in the daylight. The flames have done bad damage. His trousers have been partially burnt off, blood streaks down his legs. The Pilot’s blue eyes dart at them, in agony. He shivers violently with shock, his lips form words, his voice is a harsh whisper. (N.B. None of the German dialogue will be subtitled. We should understand only what Blake and Schofield understan

dialogues.speaker: PILOT PILOT
dialogues.text: Lazarett, Kamerad. Bitte. Military hospital, comrade. Bitte. Wasser. Water. Please. Please. Water. Water. They look down at the Pilot, shocked, unsure of what to d Schofield turns to Blake.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (sotto to Blake) We should put him out of his misery. Schofield and Blake share a look.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: No. Get him some water. He needs water. Blake kneels beside the pilot, gently cradles his head on knees. The pilot struggles, terrified and in pain. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Schofield moves to the water pump, his back to Blake and Pilot.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s alright, you’re alright. Stay still. Stay still...

dialogues.speaker: PILOT PILOT
dialogues.text: Bitte tdte mich nicht. Ich Please help me, I don't want méchte leben. to die. Schofield works the pump, the levers screeching as the mechanism creaks back to life. Creak- creak- Orange water cascades out, slapping into the metal trough Schofield keeps cranking the squeaking handle, it almost drowns out the voices behind him. Creak- creak- Schofield collects the water in his helmet. Creak- creak- Then suddenly - shouting. From behind him, piercing through the other sounds.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Stop...Stop! Schofield turns, starts forward. Blake screams in agony. Schofield moves towards him, confusion on his face, until he sees- A bloody knife in the pilot’s hand, pulled out of Blake’s abdomen.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No, no, no! Schofield grabs his rifle- He fires two shots into the pilot, killing him outright. Blake is looking down at his own bloody hands. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Bastard, bloody bastard. Blake gets to his feet, breathing heavy. Clutching his abdomen, he staggers away from the pilot’s body.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, God no. Oh, God no. Schofield watches him, scared. Blake goes for his dressings, he clumsily pulls them out his pocket, they unspool in his shaking hands. Blood is seeping through Blake’s tunic. He drops to his knees. He looks down at his own blood and sobs.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. Jesus, no. Schofield moves forward, grabs the dressing, just as Blak drops down to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: We have to stop the bleeding. Schofield wads the dressing, he moves Blake’s hand and pu the white bandage hard against Blake’s tunic, trying to s the blood. Blake shouts in pain.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Stop it. Stop it! Schofield tries to calm him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: It’s alright, it’s going to be alright. We’re going to stand up. Schofield wraps his hands around Blake’s webbing.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. Blake sets his feet. Schofield wrenches him up. Blake scr in agony.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! I can’t. I can’t. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They drop back down. Blake is pale, blood is pumping out of him, his lips are already grey.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: We have to get to an Aid Post.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I'll carry you. It isn’t very far.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Just bring a doctor here. Schofield looks around for help, there isn’t any. They ar alone.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: We can’t, we have to go together- Schofield looks at Blake, desperation in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to get up. We’re going to get up. Schofield moves behind Blake, grabs him under his arms. H lifts Blake, but Blake cannot support his own weight, his legs buckle.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Stop, please! Stop! Schofield holds him up. Begins to drag him. Schofield keeps trying to drag Blake. The more Blake struggles the more blood pisses out of his wound. Blake is suddenly wild, he screams like an animal, flaili savagely, clawing at Schofield’s chest and neck, spitting blood, struggling against him.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put me down! Put me down, you bastard, please! Put me down! They fall backwards. Schofield moves to face Blake. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake’s whole face is colourless now. Schofield looks down. His eyes land on Blake’s dressing. is scarlet now, sopping wet with blood. He swaps it for a fresh dressing. Panic swarms him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: You have to try to keep moving. Blake is weakening.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Let’s just sit... let me sit.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: We can’t. We have to find the 2nd. Remember? Your brother. We have to go now... Schofield stares down at Blake, he’s not lucid anymore. H eyes are already glazing.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: You can start on without me. I’1l1 catch up.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: You can’t stay here. We have to move, alright? We have to move. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on. That’s it. Come on, come on... Schofield wraps one arm around Blake’s back, the other ro his legs, he gets to his feet and with all his might he heaves Blake upward. Blake howls in pain. Schofield screams with the effort, giving it all he’s got But Blake is a dead weight. He can’t lift him. They drop. Schofield looks at him, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your brother. We have to find your brother. Blake’s breathing is coming in short bursts. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: You'll recognise him. Looks like me...a bit older. Schofield holds Blake’s head up. He looks impotently arou for help. Behind them the barn is crumbling in on itself, scarlet embers drift across the sky, carried on the breeze. Blake stares up at them, confused.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are they? Are we being shelled?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: They're embers, the barn is on fire. Blake looks bewildered. Then some pain creeps into his ey some awful knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I've been hit... What was it? Schofield looks down at him, unsure how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: You were stabbed. Blake looks surprised. His hand feels dumbly for his woun It lands on Schofield’s - he’s holding down the tunic, stemming what blood he can. There is blood on Blake’s lips. His breathing is becoming laboured.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Am I dying? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Yes, I think you are. An “Oh” forms on Blake’s lips. Profound sadness follows t shock. Blake reaches up slowly, and taps his tunic pocket, Schof guesses his meaning - goes to the pocket, pulls out a wal (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Inside... Schofield opens the cover, inside are a bunch of letters, a photograph - Blake, his mother, and his brother Joe. Schofield holds it up for Blake to see: yes, that's what want. Schofield puts the photograph in Blake’s hand, he presses to his breast.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you write to my mum for me?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Tell her I wasn’t scared. Schofield nods. A long beat. Schofield lets go of the pressure on Blake’s wound. He holds his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Anything else? Blake is slipping away, tears well and roll down his chee

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I love them...I wish that... I wish... It’s half strangled by sadness. A long beat. Schofield ho him. Death is close, stiffening Blake’s body, it’s alread his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Talk to me. Schofield looks at Blake, he has no idea what to say.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me you know the way.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I know the way. I’m going to head south east until I hit Ecoust. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake listens.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll pass through the town and out to the east, all the way to Croisilles Wood.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: (faint) It‘ll be dark by then.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: That won’t bother me... I'll find the 2nd, I'll give them the message, and then I’1ll find your brother. Just like you, a little older... He stops. Blake is no longer breathing. Without the lines of worry or agony on his face Blake loo very young. Schofield is still for a moment, cradling the head of Bla A long beat. Behind Schofield the barn is collapsing in o itself. The smoke has risen several stories into the sky. Schofield looks at Blake. Desperate. Then, he snaps out of it. With sudden determination, he rummages through the pockets of Blake’s tunic - takes the message for the 2nd, blood from his hands smudges on the envelope. He stows it safely in his top pocket. He pulls out the ma from Blake’s tunic. It is saturated in blood. Illegible. Schofield throws it away. He takes Blake’s rings from his lifeless hands, then open his tunic and goes for Blake’s identity disc, tearing it of the twine.
