He pries the photograph from Blake’s dead hand, looks at then leaves it face down over his heart, inside his tunic Schofield looks around them, beside the pond is a patch o long grass. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Schofield heaves Blake’s torso up - the endeavour entirel different now Blake is dead. Nothing is heavier than the dead body of someone you love

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE PARRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You alright, mate? Schofield looks up, shocked to see TWO BRITISH PRIVATES — PARRY and ATKINS.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ATKINS
dialogues.text: It’s alright, it’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE PARRY
dialogues.text: Come on, help him. Parry and Atkins move forward and take Blake’s legs. Toge the three of them move Blake to the long grass. As they m him:

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ATKINS
dialogues.text: Jesus, what happened to him? Schofield doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE PARRY
dialogues.text: Was it the plane? We saw the smoke. Schofield nods.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (sotto) Yes. They lower Blake down. Schofield kneels by his head. Lost A gentle voice, off camera.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Go fetch his things.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE PARRY PRIVATE ATKINS
dialogues.text: Sir. Yes, Sir. Parry and Atkins go to collect Schofield’s helmet and rif

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: (quietly) A friend? Schofield nods. He kneels beside Blake’s body. Impotent. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I have an urgent message for the 2nd Devons. Orders to stop tomorrow morning’s attack.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Where are they stationed?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Just beyond Ecoust.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Come with me. Smith heads back towards the farmhouse. Schofield doesn’t move. He can’t look away from Blake. Smith stops, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come with me, Corporal. That’s an order. Schofield looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're passing through Ecoust. We can take you some of the way.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir. Using the grass, he wipes Blake’s blood from off his hand He stands, drags his eyes away from Blake’s body and then moves after Smith. He collects his rifle and helmet from Parry then follows Smith through the farmhouse and back out into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small convoy of four trucks idle on the road, all caked mud and battered from their journey. Soldiers mill, smoki pissing, stretching their legs. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At the head of the small convoy is an Officer’s car. Exha fumes swirl in the still air.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL COLLINS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, come on Sergeant. Put more men at the base. At the trunk! It’1l be heavier there... The trucks are filled to the brim with SOLDIERS - a mixtu of seasoned fighters and fresh recruits. All are covered the mud of No Man’s Land.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Might be a tight squeeze. They move towards the Officer’s car. Mud hardens on the undercarriage and the wheel arches.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL COLLINS
dialogues.text: No. You’re not going to be able to just lift it. Pivot the front end to the left- At the front of the convoy a large tree trunk blocks the road, like the cherry blossoms, felled on purpose, trunk neatly chopped. Several PRIVATES and an NCO are gathered around trying to lift it. A Colonel, COLLINS (corpulent, sweating) barks orders fro the front seat of the car. Smith and Schofield approach the car.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL COLLINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the driver) Jesus. They don’t make things easy do they. They could at least have retreated with a bit of grace. Bastards.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Sir- Collins turns and looks down on Smith and Schofield, his registering confusion.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL COLLINS
dialogues.text: (registering Schofield) You're not one of mine.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No, Sir. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Collins looks at Smith for explanation.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: He’s got an urgent message to deliver to the 2nd Devons, Sir. Collins’ attention is drawn back to the tree, the men hav managed to shift it a few feet to the left.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL COLLINS
dialogues.text: (To the driver) Can you get past it?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT HARROP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL COLLINS
dialogues.text: Oh, for God’s sake. (Loudly, to the men) Just move it!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: There’s room in the casuals truck, sir. He has orders-

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL COLLINS
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, alright. (to Harrop) Come on now. You can get through there sideways. The car begins to roll forward. Smith moves off, as the Colonel’s car begins to manoeuvre way around the felled tree. Smith and Schofield walk past the row of trucks, all pack with soldiers. Schofield takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: How did you get here, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Crossed No Man’s Land just outside Bapaume. Took us the whole night. Bumped into a couple of Hun stragglers on the way who made a nuisance of themselves.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: You going up to the new line? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Attempting to. The Newfoundlands have pushed forwards and requested reinforcements. They approach the last truck. Smith looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about your friend. Schofield nods.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I tell you something that you probably already know? They stop. Schofield looks to him.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It doesn’t do to dwell on it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No, Sir. They have reached the rear of the fourth and final truck. or THREE PRIVATES mill by the rear step, smoking. They st to attention when the see the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: (to Schofield) Hop on. Smith speaks to the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make some space there... Come on, in you get! A bit of grumbling as the soldiers try to make space for A couple of the men help him up and into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty men, an amalgamation of companies - some SCOTS, so SIKHS, are crammed in here. Schofield makes space for him on the fringe. The men don’t look at Schofield, don’t muc care about the hitch-hiker. They are quiet for a beat, until Smith’s footsteps die aw and the sound of the engine rumbles. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Schofield sits silently.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Alright. Here we go again boys.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard the night bus to fuck-knows-where.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Is that a dead dog? No one answers him. Schofield looks out of the back, watching the road and th farmhouse disappear behind him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: (To Rossi) You got a fag? Rossi hands one over.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Yeah, there you go. They light their cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Butler... Oy. Carry on with that story.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: (sotto) Oh yeah, Right. So. When we get off the train, Beaufoy comes up to us and he’s having a right go - (He attempts a posh accent, complete with lisp) “Lance Corporal! Whatever one does, one never lets standards slip!” Then Scott comes out of the latrine, he wipes his hand on the back of Beaufoy’s jacket! Shit all down his back. Laughter. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Was that meant to be Captain Beaufoy?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: Oh, piss off you. You can’t do any better. Schofield pulls his bloody tunic tight around himself, watches. He almost disappears into the noise of the men.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: (Impersonating the lisp) “MEN! Your rifle stocks are an embarrassment to the entire expeditionary force.”

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: You're both bloody awful.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: You don’t know, you barely even speak the bloody language.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MALKY
dialogues.text: He’s got a better grasp of it than you, Cooke.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Go on then Jondalar, give it a go, let’s see it! The men are getting rowdier. We watch Schofield as they g on his quiet grief.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Let’s hear it then Jonny! The men noisily encourage him.

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: (Much the best impersonation - perfect lisp, gestures) “Rossi! Never in my two hundred years as a soldier have I seen such a sorry excuse for a latrine pit-” The men are all laughing, enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Shite. That is total shit! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cooke gets shouted down by the men. Someone chucks a cant at Cooke, misses.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oy! You could have taken my teeth out with that.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: You could do with a new set. Schofield is still. The laughter settles. After a beat Schofield checks his wristwatch. BUTLER sees

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: You got somewhere you need to be? The men all look at him. Suddenly, the truck lurches violently. Schofield bumps in man near him. The engine groans under them. The sounds of tyres spinning.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Oh, no... A spatter of mud is thrown up. The engine revs, but the t sinks deeper. Schofield stands, leans out of the canvas.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Arsehole needs driving lessons. A few men groan in agreement. Schofield jumps out into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield looks at the stuck wheel. The truck has driven the road trying to get round another fallen tree. Its rea wheel is sinking into a muddy ditch. Ahead, the convoy is stopped, waiting on them. Schofield speaks to one of the Privates, Cooke, as he sta at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: He should reverse. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cooke does nothing. Schofield moves to the Driver’s side the truck.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (Loudly, to the driver) Try it in reverse. REVERSE. A crunch of gears as the driver puts it in reverse. The engine revs again. Schofield bends down to look. The whee still spinning. The truck is slipping deeper.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. Stop. STOP! After a beat the sound of revving dies out and the engine idles.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone needs to get out. Some of the men climb to their feet and drop out. Others don’t move.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All out! The men aren’t moving fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: Alright, alright. Keep your bloody hair on. Begrudgingly a few fall in behind and beside the truck an ready themselves.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Right. One. Two. Three. The tyre spins on the spot, mud flies up. Schofield and t men push. Heaving together- The truck isn’t moving. But Schofield won’t stop, he pushes and pushes, groaning under the effort. Desperation etched all over his face. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: We need to get some wood, put it under the wheels. The other men drop back away from the truck frame. Schofield doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No! We haven't got the time! He puts everything he has into shifting the truck.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We all need to push! His whole body shakes with the effort.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on! COME ON! He begins to yell. Pushing, screaming in desperation.

dialogues.speaker: COME OOOON
dialogues.text: The men look at him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please. I have to go now! Please. The men see Schofield’s desperation. Recognise it. They fall back in beside him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: Alight, come on lads! Come on. Together the twenty of them push, all at once, all stretc to the very limits of their strength.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Come on, boys!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: One. Two. Three! Schofield screams in desperation.

dialogues.speaker: AAAAAAAHHHHH
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Come on boys! One last push! Yes! One. Two. Three! Suddenly, the truck moves, the wheel catches some grass a

dialogues.speaker: WHOMPH-
dialogues.text: It lurches forwards, out of the ditch. Schofield falls forward into the mud. He struggles to his knees, trying to get his emotions bac under control, struggling not to cry. Jondalar lifts him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Back in. Get back in. Go. The other men are looking at him, they see his emotion. T start to load back in. Jondalar puts his hand on Schofield’s arm. A fleeting mom of solace.

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: Are you alright? Schofield nods. TWO SOLDIERS stand on the rear step, helping to pull the others up and in. As they do-

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Here, Driver, how about you try to keep it on the bloody road for a change!

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, piss off. The men are almost all loaded in. Schofield brings up the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield takes the arm of the soldier helping men up and pulled inside. The convoy moves off. Rattling over the land. Around Schofield the men are quiet, their eyes on him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a while-

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: So, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I have to get to the 2nd Devons. Just past Ecoust.

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: They're attacking at dawn. I have orders to stop them.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MALKY
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: They're walking into a trap.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sixteen hundred. This stops them all.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: Why did they send you on your own?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: They didn’t. There were two of us. A beat. The men understand what this means.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: So now it’s down to you.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: You’1l never make it. Beat. Schofield turns to Cooke. Looks at him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Yes. I will. Butler offers Schofield some of his whisky. He takes a dr

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now all the men are looking out the back, watching the distance drop away. The truck is sweeping past a small hamlet, or at least th remains of one, houses have been reduced to skeletons, th destruction is fresh, embers still smoulder. Anything of value built on this land has been systematically destroye Dead cattle lie in the fields.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Look at it. Fucking look at it... Three years fighting over this. We should have just let the bastards keep it. I mean, who machine guns cows?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MALKY
dialogues.text: Huns with extra bullets.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Bastards. While they talk, Schofield checks that the letter is stil his pocket. He carefully puts it in his tobacco tin.

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: Clever. They know if they don’t shoot the cow, you will eat it. Rossi nods: fair point.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Still bastards.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MALKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s not even our bloody country. Brakes creak as the truck slows a little. Schofield react (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck cobbles. Schofield’ 72. (3)

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: How long gone d’you reckon they are?

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: Why? Worried we'll catch up with them?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Be a bloody miracle at this rate.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: They are probably right around the next corner.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Piss off, no they’re not.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Why don’t they just bloody well give up? Eh? Don’t they want to go home?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: They hate their wives and mothers... and Germany must be a shit hole.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: They're retreating... they’re miles back. We’ve got them on the ropes at least.

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: No. We don’t. slows down. It is juddering, as if navigating s eyes dart to the back, worried. Suddenly the truck grinds to a halt. A few ready themselv to jump out.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: Oh, bollocks. What’s up now?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: Not another bloody tree. The driver calls through the canvas. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bridge is down.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic - sotto) Oh. That’s a shame. Schofield looks out the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Looks like I’1l be getting out here. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE ROSSI
dialogues.text: Keep some of that luck for yourself pal. Think you’1ll be needing it.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BUTLER
dialogues.text: Good luck, mate.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MALKY
dialogues.text: Good luck. Drops out onto-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield jumps down into a new landscape. The land is sliced through by a huge, straight, industria canal. The sun is now below the horizon. The men from the truck watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE PRIVATE SINGER
dialogues.text: Good luck, guv. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE COOKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t balls it up.

dialogues.speaker: SEPOY JONDALAR
dialogues.text: I hope you get there.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Thank you. Captain Smith approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Next bridge is six miles. We’1l have to divert. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I can’t, Sir. I don’t have the time.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Of course. Smith offers Schofield his hand. He takes it.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best of luck.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir. Smith goes to leave, stops.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Corporal. If you do manage to get to Colonel Mackenzie, make sure there are witnesses. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: They are direct orders, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: I know. But some men just want the fight.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir. Captain Smith calls out to the driver at the head of the convoy.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SMITH
dialogues.text: Driver! Move off! Schofield watches as the small convoy drives away. Fumes swirl in its wake. He turns his attention to the new obstacle - the remains bridge, shattered and half blown - now little more than twisted metal dropping into the water. The town of Ecoust is a jagged silhouette, visible about hundred yards the other side of the canal. Smoke drifts. town is still on fire. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The canal is large and industrial - about 90 feet wide, s sides, once deep, wood and detritus float on the surface the water. On the opposite bank are the remains of a lock house. Two storeys. Windows blown in, roof half collapsed. Beyond th the remains of some small buildings, all abandoned, and t the jagged remains of Ecoust. Schofield surveys it. Looks around. All seems quiet. Eeri Schofield looks around for a way across. The blown bridge his best bet. Both sides of the metal bridge have collaps and slant down into the dark water. Schofield starts along the broken bridge, then climbs up the slim metal balustrade and starts inching downwards towards the waterline. It takes all his effort not to los his balance and fall into the water below. Finally he reaches the base of the slope, and looks acros the remaining half of the bridge. About eight feet of wat between him and the other side... He prepares himself to jump across and-

dialogues.speaker: CRACK-
dialogues.text: A gunshot slaps the water just in front of him. Birds fly Instinctively, he leaps- He lands heavily on the other side of the bridge. His foo slips into the water, and he hauls himself up with his ha He clings to the metal latticework, scrambling forward. CRACK- another shot rings out, hitting the water behind. CRACK- a bullet hits the metal near his hand. He quickly climbs across the torn carcass of the bridge towards the bank. Another bullet rings out, as he drops down, throwing hims into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cover of the far bank wall. He rips in breaths as he presses his body into the stone bank. He stays low, inchi along the side until he can get a sense of where the shot are coming from. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He looks. Now he can register the direction of the shots. SHOOTER, in the lock house. On the upper floor. A single window. Schofield slides along the bank until he hits a small stairwell set into the wall of the canal bank. Barely eno cover, but his only option. CRACK. Another bullet sings against the stone as he darts the other side of the stairs. Schofield readies his rifle, his hands are ice, and injur and slow to work. They shake violently as he tries to che and load the weapon. Panting, he tries to still his trembling body as he creep to the top of the stairs, he peers over the top step to l up his shot. CRACK- a bullet sings off the stone next to his head. He sucks in a deep breath and holds it. He exhales as he leans into the shadow of the wall, and readies his rifle. Schofield lifts his body above the wall, and fires once. CRACK. Quickly, the shooter fires back. Schofield aims again, CRACK. The shooting stops. Silence. Schofield is still for a moment. Breathing heavy. Shaking from the cold and from adrenalin. He spins and fires another two shots through the window o the lock house. CRACK. CRACK. Wood splinters. He waits. Again, silence. He steadies himself and stands carefully, rifle ready, an quickly advances to the lock house. He pushes open the do and moves inside.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No movement on the ground floor. The staircase is ahead of him. His ears burn listening fo any sounds, any hint of movement. He holds his breath, the wood creaks under him as he back against the wall, rifle pointing to the top of the stairc Staying low and against the wall he moves upwards. Parts the upstairs come into view - He can now see the door to the upper room. Slowly, he moves along the short corridor. With his foot, Schofield pushes at the door. It swings open, agonisingly slowly, creaking on its hinges. Revealing- A GERMAN SOLDIER, slumped against the far wall, wounded - with his gun raised. A split second to react, Schofield raises his rifle and

dialogues.speaker: BOOM-BOOM
dialogues.text: Both guns go off at the same time. The German's bullet hits Schofield on the helmet, ripping neck and upper body backwards, almost lifting him off his feet. Schofield stumbles backwards and falls- Down the stairs. BAM - he hits the stone at the foot of the stairs and... Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still black. In the darkness the sound of a single drip. Out of the darkness, Schofield'’s face. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The drip comes from a hole in the ceiling, and falls on Schofield’s forehead. He opens his eyes. Schofield starts to move, gingerly. He lifts his hand wit difficulty, runs it along the back of his head. Looks at slick with black blood. He sits up, begins to focus. His face and hair are wet. H legs are sprawled on the stairs above him. He looks aroun dumbly. Unsure of what is up and what is down. He looks at his watch - smashed in the fall. No idea what time it is. Panic begins to claw at him. He has somewhere to be. If o he could remember it. He looks around for his rifle. He spots it above him, at top of the stairs. He crawls towards it. Reaches it. Suddenly, the room fills with light. Outside, a flare str across the sky. As the light swings across the room, Schofield now sees the German soldier lying dead, slumped against the wall. Schofield stands and gradually descends the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. Then, another flare hisses across the black sky, light bu from it. It falls slowly to earth, the magnesium light blinding. As the light falls the whole world undulates before him. clear to him if he is awake or dreaming. The falling flare is playing with reality; shapes and sha warp across the land. There has been a rainstorm. The outlines of destroyed buildings contract and expands ahead of him. He begins to stagger forwards through Ecoust. Struggling pick his way through shifting spots of darkness, unable t tell what is shadow and what is a ditch. The puddles refl the Verey light, glowing as it falls, stinging his eyes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CRACK - A gunshot. Somewhere in the darkness there is ano sniper. A brief moment of confusion, as he looks around for the source of the gunshot. CRACK. Another gunshot. Distant shouts. Schofield begins run. He runs at full pelt. As he does, the flare light dies. N he is careening through shapeless darkness. We are running blind, with Schofield. The sound of his footfalls, his breathing. He crashes through a puddle, the noise draws shots. The bullets buzz around him in the darkness. Then - HISS - another flare bursts above him. He flings himself down in the rubble. Shots clip the ground around him. Schofield lies motionle breathing heavily, trying to disappear into the rubble ar him, waiting for the light to die. He looks up, trying to memorize his next path as the ligh moves the ground ahead of him. The light dies. Schofield is up and clattering in darkness across cobbles Another flare goes up into the night sky, but this time Schofield doesn’t stop. He keeps running. It sweeps directly over him, he darts into the bombed out remains of a shop. As the light from the flare dies above him, he turns the corner into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narrow, dark. He starts to move along the alley. Feeling safe in the blackness, heading towards the flickering light at the en the alley -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield looks both ways. A broad main market street stretches away in both directions. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: All windows are smashed, buildings have been shelled and collapsed in on themselves. Some have vanished altogether Schofield cautiously peers out along the wide street. To left, at the far end of the street, is a Main Square, fra by a colonnade. Beyond, just out of sight, something large is burning. Schofield checks both ways, then begins to walk down the ruins of the empty street, towards the square. Wary. Large medieval colonnades flank the entrance to the squar some have crumbled. Schofield slips through them and into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield stops under the columns. The destruction here i staggering - Colonnades run around most of the square, massive section it are pitted with gaps. Whole buildings are gone, like missing teeth - blackness yawns in them. Entire storeys h fallen away, revealing empty rooms. At the centre of the square, the remains of a fountain. In the far corner of the square the Church is on fire. Th firelight reflects off the wet cobblestones and puddles. Schofield stares at it. Awed. Then he spots something- In front of the bright flames: A MAN’S SILHOUETTE. Schofield sees him. The Man stops, lowers his weapon. Sta to walk towards him. Schofield cannot make out if he is a German or British soldier and begins to move towards him. Suddenly the Man lifts his gun and starts to run, heading straight towards Schofield. It’s A GERMAN SOLDIER. Schofield responds quickly. He takes off running, heading through the colonnade. The Soldier raises hie rifles and fires after him. Schofield doesn’t stop, heading out of the square and int  81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can hear the shouts of the Soldier coming after him. Schofield runs full tilt. He turns a corner. Ahead, to hi left, at about knee height, is a low cellar window. He heads towards it, grabs at it. It’s locked. He can hear the footsteps of the soldier getting closer. Beside the window is a coal chute. In a flash, Schofield on his hands and knees through the dark opening, scrambli into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pitch black while his eyes adjust. He clutches his rifle, steps back into the shadows. His breath saws in and out, he listens to the slap of running footsteps getting closer. Schofield slides down into the darkness as a pair of Germ boots run by the low window. He stays crouched in the darkness for a time, listening t the footsteps receding. His eyes finally leave the window look around him. He is in a low-ceilinged coal cellar. Sections of the roo above have collapsed, letting in drips of rain and some f light. The room is empty. Then something catches his eye. At the far end of the room, a small doorway. Heavy fabric been hung across it. His eyes catch the flicker of flame escaping through material. Schofield readies his rifle. He points it at the curtain, ready to fire, gun cocked- Carefully he advances into the small room. Pushes the fab aside with his rifle. In the centre of the room a furnace, presumably used to h the house. A small makeshift fire has been lit in it. Aro the fire a couple of blankets, some firewood, empty cans, crusts of stale bread. As Schofield’s eyes adjust to the light, he sees movement the shadows. Instinctively, he lifts his rifle. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is a woman crouched in the corner. LAURI, late teen frail and hollow-eyed. Her eyes fill with fear when she sees Schofield enter her hiding place. She doesn’t move to flee - there is nowhere go.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles; pleading) (subtitles) Il ny rien ici. Nous n'avons There is nothing here. We rien pour vous. S'il vous have nothing for you. Please. plait. Schofield sets his rifle down, holds his hands up, as if say: I am not a threat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Anglais. Not German. Friend... I’m a friend. She calms a little. He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This place, this town. Ecoust? C'est Ecoust? Lauri nods.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) Oui. Schofield looks relieved. He suddenly begins to feel the pain in his head. He sways little.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) Ou sont les autres? Where are the others? She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Others? No. Just me. She looks. He gestures.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only. Me. She understands. A beat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to be somewhere... I need to find a wood to the South East? Lauri looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trees... les arbres? Schofield searches his woozy head.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Croiset?

dialogues.speaker: LAURI
dialogues.text: Croisilles? Schofield nods.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Yes. Lauri points out the direction.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) La riviére- The river-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: River?

dialogues.speaker: LAURI
dialogues.text: River. It go there. Trees. Croisilles. A little wave of relief. He tenderly touches his bleeding head with his hand, winces with the pain, reels with naus

dialogues.speaker: LAURI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) Assiez-toi. Sit down. She motions for Schofield to sit, pointing at a chair nea the fire. He sways, but doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Asseyez vous. Monsieur. Sit down. Sir. He understands enough to obey her. Swaying slightly he dr into the chair. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Still holding his hand to his head, he closes his eyes an feels the warmth of the fire on his face. It makes him al delirious. Lauri watches him. She slowly moves over to Schofield and places her hand on his. He jumps at her touch. Tenderness foreign to him.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shhh. Shhh. Her kindness translates. She inspects the wound. She carefully parts his damp hair finds the jagged wound. He flinches. She is very close to him, he can feel her breath on his n She reaches down, takes out a handkerchief, holds it agai the wound. He closes his eyes, relaxes against her touch. Lauri looks at Schofield, his eyes closed, his uniform ca in blood and mud. At last he turns back to face her. They lock eyes. A beat

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (quietly) Thank you. Then, from behind her comes a sound. Something soft, smal BABY stirring. Schofield starts. Lauri moves to the corner of the room. An old mattress li on the floor. Next to it, a drawer from an old chest has lined with cloth. She reaches in, lifts the child, cradle protectively.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) Ma petite. My little one. Schofield stares at the baby as it settles in her arms. I can’t be more than five months old.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: A girl? She nods her head. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) Qui. Une fille. Yes. A girl. Schofield smiles. A long beat. The baby is waking, she begins to cry. Lauri soothes her. Schofield kneels down bedside them. The baby is soothed, she settles.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: What is her name? Lauri looks to Schofield, desolate. Shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) J'ne sais pas. I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Who is her mother?

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) J'ne sais pas. I don't know. The sadness nearly drowns them both. A long beat. Schofield opens his pack and rummages -

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I have food. Here. I have these. You can have them - here, take them all, for you and the child. Here. He empties his rations onto the mattress, a bounty in thi barren place. Lauri looks at them, aching with hopelessne Schofield doesn’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) Elle ne peut pas manger ga. She can not eat that. She Elle a besoin de lait... needs milk... She searches for the word in English- Schofield blinks at her, in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Milk. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lauri nods. Schofield’s cold fingers pry the canteen from his belt. H opens it and hands it to her. She looks at him in wonder. smells the canteen. Milk. Lauri looks up at him, amazement and gratitude etched ont her tired features.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI
dialogues.text: Merci. The baby is fussing. Schofield moves closer, gently talking to the child.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Bonjour. The baby’s bright eyes latch on to his.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bonjour. The baby looks at him. Begins to settle.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) Avez-vous des enfants? Do you have children? Children - you? Children - you? He doesn’t answer. He watches the baby.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Shhhh... It’s alright...

dialogues.speaker: LAURI LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) (subtitles) Elle vous aime. Continuez... She likes you. Continue ... continuez a parler. keep talking. Schofield looks at the child, searching for something to He says the first thing that comes into his head. He speaks softly, like he’s done it before...

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: “They went to sea in a Sieve, they did, (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In a Sieve they went to sea: In spite of all their friends could say, On a winter's morn, on a stormy day, In a Sieve they went to sea." The baby’s eyes don’t leave Schofield.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Far and few, far and few, Are the lands where the Jumblies live; Their heads are green, and their hands are blue, And they went to sea in a Sieve." A beat. The baby has settled, hypnotised by the sound. They are still for a moment in the firelight. Suddenly, the distant church bell tolls. The noise rolls through the quiet cellar. Schofield starts at the sound. He counts the clock strikes in his head as they happen. TWO... THREE... He keeps looking down at the baby, but his eyes are filli with fear. FOUR...FIVE... His heart is sinking. SIX. He holds his breath. Silence. He stands. Goes for his pack. Lauri watches him, confused

dialogues.speaker: LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) Le jour. Les soldats vont vous voir... They see you. Il fera jour. Vous devriez attendre. Stay. Stay. Please.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: LAURI
dialogues.text: (subtitles) The morning. The soldiers will see you. They see you. It will be light. You should wait. Stay. Stay. Please. Schofield takes his rifle and moves to the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes through the doorway. Damaged wooden stairs lead Schofield slips over the rubble, over the remains of the house. He peers along the empty street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield stays in the shadows, and begins to work his wa along the street in the direction Lauri pointed him. The town is silent. He looks up at the sky to see if the is rising. No light. He reaches a crossroads - small alleyways branch off. He looks around. Lost. He turns to his right - a wide alleyw He moves along it, quickly, quietly. BANG - ahead of him a door flies open, warm light spills onto the street, followed by a German soldier. PRIVATE MULLER, 30s, blind drunk. Muller stumbles a few steps and then vomits. Moaning and muttering to himself. Schofield ducks into the darkness of a doorway. Muller moans and pukes again. Schofield backs inside the doorway and into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small school assembly hall and a couple of other rooms been blown together into one large space. Metal beams whe there once was a roof. A few school desks, tipped onto th sides. To one side of the room, wide arched windows let in shaft light from the burning church outside. They streak across inky darkness. At the far end of the room is the door Private Muller jus exited. A small fire burns on the floor by it. Smoke hang the room. A couple of empty bottles lie around. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Schofield stays in the shadows. Silently scanning the darkness, listening to the pathetic moans of Muller outsi He looks around, searching for another way out, a way pas Muller. Out of the shadows steps a man - ANOTHER GERMAN SOLDIER - BAUMER, late teens. He is doing up his flies. They lock eyes, three feet apart. A beat - shock on both their faces, then horror. Neither them want this. Baumer opens his mouth to scream. Schofield closes the three feet and is on him - pushing Baumer hard against a pillar. Schofield holds Baumer there, his hand clamped over the y soldiers mouth. They lock eyes. Schofield holds his finge his lips: Stay quiet. Baumer nods. Schofield slowly drops his hand from Baumer’s mouth. Wary Baumer sucks in a breath and shouts out:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMER BAUMER
dialogues.text: Englander! English! Schofield reacts quickly, ramming his palm into Baumer’s mouth, gagging him as they both fall onto the hard ground the sound echoes loudly though the school house. Baumer bites down on Schofield’s hand, still bound with i bandage. Schofield gasps out, gritting his teeth against the pain. forces his hand further into Baumer’s mouth, his other ha goes to the boys throat - squeezing with all his strength Baumer has a knife. Schofield wrestles it out of his hand Baumer thrashes and kicks under Schofield, rolling the tw them to the side. They are two feral creatures - both know this is to the death. A shadow at the far end of the room. Muller is coming bac (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MULLER PRIVATE MULLER
dialogues.text: Mein Gott Baumer... Das war Christ Baumer... This was a ein Fehler. Wir sollten heute mistake. We should go back Abend zuriick gehen. tonight, maybe no one will Vielleicht hat niemand notice we've gone. gemerkt, dass wir weg waren. Muller staggers his way over to a spot by the fire, slump down. Rummages among the empty bottles. Baumer tears a breath in through his nostrils, tries to scream — Schofield squeezes harder on the boy’s neck, pushing the boy’s head down into the ground. Crushing him into the br glass and debris.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MULLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wo ist der Brandy? Du kleiner Where's the brandy? You Scheisser.. wehe du bist little shit, you better not damit fortgelaufen. have run off with it. Desperately, Baumer beats his hands against Schofield’s chest. Muller hears the noise. Muller turns and peers towards them. He can’t see them in shadows.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MULLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Baumer. Wo ist..? Baumer? Baumer. Where is..? Baumer? But Schofield can see him, and his focus briefly shifts. In that moment, Baumer fights back - Kicking, clawing, punching. But he is weaker now. Schofield redoubles his efforts. His hands and arms ache. Acid stings in his musc Schofield is desperate. His eyes flick between Muller and Baumer. Baumer’s feet scratch and scrape frantically on the stone

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE MULLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Baumer? Baumer? Muller stands, teeters towards them. Then - Baumer’s arms fall limp. Schofield snaps up, leaving his rifle behind him, and lea out of the shadows. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He barges straight past Muller, heading for the door at t far end of the room. Muller staggers back -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield is out of the door, running, hands free, breath sawing in his ears. The sound of Muller behind him-

dialogues.speaker: ENGLANDER
dialogues.text: Muller’s howl chases Schofield along the street. The soun the door swinging open echoes after him. Schofield doesn’t stop. Behind him is the sound of Muller giving chase then-

dialogues.speaker: CRACK-
dialogues.text: A bullet sings off the wall opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield sprints, looking over his shoulder. He turns... and fifty yards in front him - Another German Soldier. The same man who chased him acros the square. The soldier breaks into a run, reaches for hi rifle. The soldier shoots, but Schofield breaks left across the street and into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow alley. Schofield darts down it, looking for some escape. Muller and the other German race into the alley behind hi Shots burst on the wall next to Schofield. To his left is another corner, Schofield sprints for it. out into -  92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead of Schofield is a flight of stone steps. He leaps down. Taking them three or four at a time. He slams against the wall, leaps down another flight. His breath burns in his lungs. At the bottom of the stair is a long straight street, about 100 yards. Leading to a Bridge. Schofield runs towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His heartbeat thunders as he sprints flat out. The street slopes downhill. Yards fall under him. We can see the burning Town receding behind him. The sound of the Two Germans battering down the stairs ec after him. They hit the flat street. 30 yards behind him. They open fire. Bullets crack off the cobbles just in front of him. He is 50 yards from the bridge, running full tilt. Shots ring out. Schofield reaches the bridge. Bullets ring off the rubble He keeps sprinting. And suddenly, with no warning, Schofield veers across the street, puts one hand on the stone wall of the bridge... -..and vaults clean over it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield drops forty feet and smashes into the water. We are under the dark water. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Schofield resurfaces, gasping for air. Numb, panicking, h thrashes and kicks, fighting the weight, the cold, the fe He struggles to slip off his webbing. It tangles up in hi arms, pulling him down. Finally he gets it off, it is swallowed up in the white w which churns all around him. Losing the weight of the webbing, he manages to stay abov the water. The bridge and the German soldiers are long gone. The wat is fast flowing after the rain, rapids sweep him along. A felled tree lies across the river. Schofield grabs hold its branches, tries to pull himself up. But the torrent i too strong to fight. It rips his hands away, and pulls hi under again. He surfaces. Coughs and splutters on the water line. The rapids continue to pull him through the water at spee Schofield goes with it. Letting the water carry him. He scans the river banks ahead. They tower up steeply. He looks for a way out. Around him, rocks jut out from the w dangerously. They churn the river into a whirlpool, spinn him around. He is now traveling backwards downstream. Behind him, a large rock rises up out of the water. He is approaching it fast. He doesn’t see it. The water drives him hard into the rock. His back and hea are slammed against it. Schofield is winded, disorientated, barely staying afloat Ahead there is a sound. A deep rumbling. He fights to keep his ears above the water, to hear it. The rapids are getting faster, more turbulent. Schofield realizes what the sound is - the roar of water. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Panic flashes on his face. He thrashes, tries to swim to bank. But it’s too late. A waterfall lies ahead. He braces himself, and then the waterfall is on him ina flash. Schofield goes over it. He is pulled down into the plunge pool. We lose sight of him. And then, nothing. He is gone. For a few moments, just the roar of the falls. Then, suddenly Schofield resurfaces, gasping for air. The churning water pushes him free of the falls. He manag to turn onto his back. The river has got wider, deeper. He grabs hold of a branc The current carries him. The world around him has turned in the pre-dawn light. The river sweeps him forward. He is still gasping for bre Now the tumbling river gradually begins to smooth out int cool apron of water. Schofield is almost unconscious. He is slipping down, his mouth just above the waterline. His eyes flutter and open, he spits out water. Grey mistrals roll through a pale world. Unearthly. They hover above the river ahead. The river slowly pulls him. Occasional trees line the ban This place is untouched by war. Spared. Clean and cool an filled with some life. Schofield is fighting it, but ready to accept that this i the end. He knows too well there are worse places, worse ways... Inch by inch he starts to slip down. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His ears fall under the waterline. The sound is sucked fr the world. His eyes stare upwards. Lips just above the wa Schofield seems so peaceful, just floating on the water. sound of the falls recedes. We are aware of birds, the wind in the leaves. Then the water around him turns flat. The current begins slow. White. Petals float on it, a patchwork blanket. Cherry Blossom. Schofield is swept through the white petals. Schofield raises an arm from the water and sees the petal clinging to him. Blake. A long beat. Life seeps back into him, breaks through the icy numbness Schofield’s limbs struggle to work in the cold. He fights, willing movement. He swims towards the bank. Ahead there are the sounds of a dam: a gentle fountain of water. The sun is rising somewhere - the pre-dawn light is begin to illuminate the world around him. He has reached the dam - a fallen tree. He begins to haul himself out. He looks down. BODIES. Twelve bodies, give or take. SOLDIERS - British, German. And CIVILIANS. Men and women. They have caught and gathered, blocked by the tree from floating downstream. They have formed a kind of dam. He takes the only option. He pulls himself up, and climbs across the bodies. His way out. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He makes it to the river bank, and stumbles up onto the slope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drags himself across the grass, and collapses to his knees. He cries. Big racking sobs - for the river, for life, for Blake, fo the baby. The morning is forming. Far off in the distance, something foreign, or long forgotten. Music. Singing. Schofield listens. Then slowly gets up, walks, shaking, towards the sound. He stumbles but doesn’t fall. His froz limbs are forced, dragged, back to life. Schofield moves up the steep rise. He stops and looks at woods that now lie ahead of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shafts of morning light stream through the pine trees. Schofield walks towards the music. Uncertain if it is rea The music is in the air, a canopy, almost directionless. can now make out a voice. And words.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...there is no sickness, toil, nor danger/In that bright land to which I go... Schofield picks his way through the thin trees... and suddenly the music has a source. A YOUNG SOLDIER stands in a small clearing. A British COMPANY - about two hundred men - are gathered around listening. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The young soldier’s voice is pure, untrained. He sings th old folk song - “I Am A Poor Wayfaring Stranger".

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOLDIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m going there to see my Father, And all my loved ones who’ve gone on. Schofield stops on the edge of the clearing. Unsettled by world before him. Unsure if these men are living or dead. If he is one of these ghosts. He leans against a tree and slumps down on the outskirts the group. The music washes over him. Dawn is breaking. He closes his eyes. Done.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m only going over Jordan I’m only going over home. The song finishes. A smattering of applause.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: D Company! MOVE OUT! The men stand up and begin to move. Then a voice.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR
dialogues.text: You alright pal? Schofield opens his eyes. A pair of legs before him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you from? Another pair of legs.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE GREY
dialogues.text: He’s probably got the wind up.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR
dialogues.text: Well he’s not one of ours.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BULLEN
dialogues.text: He’s bloody soaked. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE GREY
dialogues.text: Fuck it, let’s just pick him up and take him with us.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (very faintly) Have to find the Devons.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE GREY
dialogues.text: What’s he saying?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR
dialogues.text: What’s that mate?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: The Devons. I have to find the Devons. A pause while the soldiers share a look. Schofield Schofield

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR
dialogues.text: We’re the Devons. looks up at them, disbelief on his face.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: You’re the Devons.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR
dialogues.text: Yes, Corp.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Why haven’t you gone over?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE BULLEN
dialogues.text: We’re the second wave.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE WILLOCK
dialogues.text: They don’t send us all at once.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR
dialogues.text: We’re D Company, we spent the night digging in. We go last. staggers to his feet. His hand goes to his tunic pocket, to the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you all right? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Mackenzie. Where’s Colonel Mackenzie?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR
dialogues.text: He’s down at the line.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR
dialogues.text: This way. We’re headed up there now. Schofield takes off down the line of men, shoving and pus his way as the queue of them winds out of the woods. We hear Seymour behind him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE SEYMOUR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oy! Steady on mate! Where you going? Schofield reaches the edge of the wood. From the break in trees he can see the land stretching ahead of him. The one-day-old British trench, is perhaps forty yards aw and beyond it, far in the distance, on the higher ground black ribbon across the land: The German trenches. From h you can just begin to sense the scale of it. A comms trench leads to the front line. Schofield stagger down into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield begins to run along the comms trench, stumbling weaving in and out of the advancing line of soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Move! We catch glimpses of the men as Schofield passes -

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me by - Move! Let me through! He grabs the first Corporal he sees by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s your commanding officer? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LANCE CORPORAL DUFF
dialogues.text: He’s in the holding pen. Schofield sprints in that direction - shoving and barging now. As he approaches the Holding Area, we can see THRONGS of SOLDIERS - The 2nd A and B Companies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The holding area is packed with men.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT HUTTON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: B Company, stand to! Now listen, and listen well! Schofield spots the commanding voice, pushes through towa the Lieutenant-

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT HUTTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On the first mark, A Company will advance! B Company will then move to the front line!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir, I have a message from General Erinmore!

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT HUTTON
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: The attack has been called off. General Erinmore has called off the attack. The Lieutenant stares at Schofield, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT HUTTON
dialogues.text: Balls, man. We’re about to go over. We’ve got them on the run.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (frantic) You don’t! Please. Don’t send your men over.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT HUTTON
dialogues.text: Get out of the way, Corporal - (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: These are direct orders from Army command! Where is the Colonel Mackenzie? Schofield brandishes his letter. Still wet from the river but legible. He looks like a madman. Hutton grabs him by lapels.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT HUTTON
dialogues.text: (furious) Jesus Christ, man! Go and see the Captain! Hutton shoves him away. Schofield staggers on, pushing ou the holding area. As he goes, we hear Hutton bellowing to men-

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT HUTTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I want us up there quickly, you understand? Do you understand! Hutton’s men respond: ‘Yes, Sir!’ etc. Schofield rushes through them and into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The narrow trench is packed with more men. This trench is hastily dug. Little more than a temporary berm, perhaps five feet high. Hundreds of men crouch just inside the trench wall, waiting, preparing. He pushes past more men. And still more.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT WRIGHT
dialogues.text: Sections 9 and 10 at the ready! We will advance on the first whistle blast! Schofield pushes forwards.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT GARDNER
dialogues.text: You must not slow down! If the man next to you falls, keep moving! Your orders are to break the lines -

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Where is the Captain? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gardner nods to CAPTAIN IVINS, rocking back and forth, he bowed.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT GARDNER
dialogues.text: He’s over there. Schofield gets to Ivins.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir? Sir! Ivins looks up at Schofield, he’s crying, muttering to himself, terrified. Tears roll down his face.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Captain, I have a message. This attack is called off. You have to stop, you have to stop - Before he can say more, the air vibrates. An impossibly l sound - GERMAN ARTILLERY. Shells scream overhead and then - a wall of noise. The air seems to tremble. SOLDIERS press themselves into the walls of the trench, t cover wherever they can. The earth groans as the shells land. Pounding the earth a around. Not yet zeroed in on the British Line.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN IVINS
dialogues.text: (Soundlessly) No. No. No. Schofield grabs Ivins.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (Shouting, soundless) Where is Colonel Mackenzie? Men cover their ears and squeeze their skulls, but the so still drowns them. Captain Ivins has his hands over his e Schofield tries to wrestle his arms away, so he can be he

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Again, soundless) Where is Mackenzie? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: No response. The noise is too much. Some men push their heads against the front wall of the trench, scream into the mud, all voices are lost. Others cower into the earth. The noise is unbearable. Schofield leaves Ivins, moving faster through the line no men crouch and contort themselves low. Schofield pushes forwards. Then, twenty yards behind Schofield - a direct hit. The concussion of the blast ripples along the narrow tren The walls literally bleed earth and chalk. In an instant IVINS, his men, the entire section of trenc they were in has vanished. They simply disappear -— Schofield is thrown forward, into a huddle of stunned men Sound creeps back into the world, raspy screams over the thunder of explosions. We can hear a voice in the distanc

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT GARDNER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Bearers! Stretcher bearers! Schofield drags himself to his feet, keeps moving along t trench. German shells whistle through the air all around. Schofield pushes his way along. Fountains of mud and iron burst in No Man’s Land, towerin into the sky, showering dirt and shrapnel onto the line. Schofield doesn’t stop running, pushing through A and B Companies. The trench gets thinner, tapering in- Schofield fights through the men now, running out of spac running out of time. The trench narrows until Schofield can’t get through the The PLATOONS have lost their form here, there are no gaps between them, everyone is packed together in the chaos. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The German artillery is increasing now. Every moment is rocked with noise. There is no space, no silence. Ahead of him, 100 yards down, the trench takes another di hit. But Schofield keeps moving towards it. MEN flow away from the damage. Pushing their way towards Schofield. Completely blocking the trench. Schofield pushes forward until the trench becomes impassa A wall of men, with nowhere to go. A burly Sergeant is ahead of him, brandishing a pistol, yelling commands, trying to regain some sort of order, bu his words are lost in the roar of the shells.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT GUTHRIE
dialogues.text: GET BACK! Return to your sectors. GET BACK! BACK! Hold fast! Schofield pushes past him, and finds the nearest C.0O. - LIEUTENANT RICHARDS. His eyes are on his men, revolver in hand.

dialogues.speaker: SEVEN PLATOON
dialogues.text: Schofield grabs at him, screams-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir, I have orders to stop this attack. Richards wants to believe him.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT RICHARDS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Where is Colonel Mackenzie?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT RICHARDS
dialogues.text: He’s further up the line.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: How far?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Three hundred yards. He’s in a cut and cover. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Both of them look around.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT RICHARDS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll have to wait until the first wave goes over.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No! No, I can’t! Schofield turns and looks. More shells hit the trench. Ch The way to Mackenzie is impassable. Panic mingles with despair. Richards turns back to his men.

dialogues.speaker: PLATOON
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Schofield climbs up onto the firing step... Richards turns and sees him.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT RICHARDS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can’t possibly make it that way man, are you bloody insane? 300 yards. Open ground, utterly without cover. It may as be on the moon. Everything slows. Something in Schofield snaps.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT RICHARDS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing, Lance Corporal? Schofield is on the top step... He stands.

dialogues.speaker: NO, NO, NO, NO
dialogues.text: Richards and his men watch on in disbelief, as an unarmed Schofield staggers out and into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield stumbles forwards. Shocked that he is now out i the open. Then he starts to run, picking up speed. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now Schofield is sprinting full pelt, parallel to the tre His breath burns in and out, sawing in his ears Schofield doesn’t stop. His legs thump over the earth. We hear the screech of the whistle. Three short blasts. The roar of hundreds of men follows-— Schofield keeps sprinting to the western trench as now, S HUNDRED SOLDIERS pour out of the British front line- Running out into No Man’s Land, and crossing in front and behind Schofield. Hundreds of soldiers, heading towards the German lines as keeps sprinting to the western trench. The German guns now erupt again. Men fall in their dozens. Hundreds more pour over the top. Schofield is only half way. He stumbles, falls. But picks himself up and keeps on running. The whole world shakes on its axis as the shells land. The air thunders around him. The ground itself bursts and rolls. A Company are still pouring out into No Man’s Land. Schofield is running, running. Through the hail of bullets and shells. Still running. His lungs burn, his breath grates in his throat as he run Behind him, men continue to pour over the top. Schofield sprints the final few feet and - He jumps desperately into -  107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tumbles and lands amongst the waiting men of B Company now in the breech. Schofield careens through them and hits the ground hard. Men look down at him in horror. He brandishes his message a Captain, SANDBACH, closes in on him-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: (Breathless) Colonel Mackenzie? The Captain helps Schofield to his feet and pushes him in direction of a dugout-

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SANDBACH
dialogues.text: He’s in there. (he turns to his men) B Company two minutes! There is a lull in the shelling, the earth still rumbles above them with the sounds of distant machine guns, but t blasts have stopped. Schofield runs, half limping, cutting through the men who about to be sent over the top, and pushes his way to the entrance of a dugout.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Let me through!

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY DIXON
dialogues.text: Hey, hey...!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Let me through! Schofield drops down a few steps, a second orderly, BYRNE grabs him. Schofield tries to get past.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY BYRNE
dialogues.text: (overlapping) What the hell do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I have to get through. I have to see Colonel Mackenzie! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY DIXON
dialogues.text: What are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I have to stop this attack- He pushes past Dixon and into- INT. MACKENZIE’S DUGOUT ANTE-ROOM —- CONTINUOUS The two Orderlies have Schofield by the arms now. He has strength left to fight them. His voice is lost in melee, as CAPTAIN RYLANDS sweeps pas him and in-

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN RYLANDS
dialogues.text: Colonel, we’ve seen flares, the men on the left flank have made it to the German Line-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Colonel!

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY DIXON
dialogues.text: Hold him!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Colonel! The Orderlies haul him out of the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield struggles wildly against the orderlies, they ha him pinned against the trench wall.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Listen to me, listen to me! I have a letter! I need to see Colonel MacKenzie! The Orderlies yell over him.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY BYRNE
dialogues.text: There’s no bloody way you're getting in there, mate! Captain Rylands exits the dugout and bellows down the sec to two Sergeants. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN RYLANDS
dialogues.text: Sergeant! Send the next wave! The Sergeants yell back in the affirmative from further d the line.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No! With the last of his strength, Schofield throws his elbow into the stomach of one of the orderlies. He breaks away them and into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield careens into the room. A huddle of OFFICERS are inside, their backs to him. A commanding voice emanates f among them.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tell Ivins and Murphy to direct their men to the left flank. Concentrate everything there.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: The officers turn on Schofield, parting as they do. In th centre, staring straight at him, is COLONEL MACKENZIE, 40 Mackenzie stands ramrod straight, and is immaculately tur out, despite the chaos surrounding him. He has a small sc across his left eye.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in a rush) Sir, this attack is not to go ahead! You’ve been ordered to stop. You have to stop.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Lance Corporal Schofield, Sir. 8th. I have orders from General Erinmore to call off this attack. Schofield offers up the letter. The other Officers all re But Mackenzie doesn’t take it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: You’re too late, Lance Corporal.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir, these orders are from Army Command. You have to read them. He holds out the letter to Mackenzie. A damp scrap of pap A Major, HEPBURN, is listening closely.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HEPBURN
dialogues.text: Shall we hold back the second wave, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: No, Major. Hesitate now and we lose. Victory is five hundred yards away. Mackenzie is resolute.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir...Sir! Please read the letter.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: I have heard it all before. I’m not going to wait until dusk, or for fog. I’m not calling back my men, only to send them out there again tomorrow. Not when we've got the bastards on the run. This is their last stand.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: The German's planned this, Sir. They've been planning it for months. They want you to attack. Read the letter. This catches MacKenzie’s attention. He nods to Major Hepb get the letter. Hepburn takes the letter from Schofield, hands it to Colo MacKenzie. MacKenzie opens it. Reads. His face utterly impassive. Inscrutable. Schofield waits. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: Major.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HEPBURN
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. A horrible moment of silence. Everything hangs on this.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: Stand them down.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HEPBURN
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. Schofield closes his eyes. Relief floods his body. The Major runs from the dugout, a blast of whistles from outside - a signal to stop. Mackenzie addresses his other officers.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: Call up the orderlies. Tend the wounded. Hold the line in case they counter.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICERS
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. The Officers empty out of the dugout. Noises of orders be shouted and whistles being blown seep in from outside. A long beat. Schofield senses Mackenzie moving closer to They are now alone. Mackenzie speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE
dialogues.text: I hoped today might be a good day. Hope is a dangerous thing. Schofield stands stock still.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s it for now. Then next week, Command will send a different message. Attack at dawn. Mackenzie looks him in the eye. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is only one way this war ends. Last man standing. Mackenzie looks him up and down.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have someone see to your wounds. Schofield is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MACKENZIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now fuck off, Lance Corporal. Schofield leaves the main dugout. Major Hepburn stands ju outside the door. He grabs Schofield’s arm as he passes. Schofield turns.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HEPBURN
dialogues.text: (heartfelt) Well done, lad.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know where Lieutenant Blake is, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HEPBURN
dialogues.text: Blake?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: There were two of us. I was sent here with his brother. He looks at him. The Major understands.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HEPBURN
dialogues.text: Ah. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HEPBURN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, knowing Lieutenant Blake he would have gone over with his men. He was in the first wave.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: How could I find him, Sir? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HEPBURN
dialogues.text: You can try the casualty clearing station, behind the line. Otherwise... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL CAIRNS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Major Hepburn, Sir! He leaves. A beat while Schofield orientates himself. The turns and walks out into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds of the wounded and the dying as they pass. The German guns have stopped for now. A brief pause. Schofield walks along the line. The B, C and D Companies are gathered, pulling in the survivors, carrying dying and wounded men along the trenc Lifting them by hand where they have no stretchers. Schofield continues along. Searching for officers, for Lieutenant Blake. No one looks at him. No one sees him. H slips past them, a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schofield turns the corner, and pushes his way along the zag length of the trench. STRETCHER BEARERS push past him, pressing him against the back wall as they pass with the wounded.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sergeant, I have to find Lieutenant Blake. Do you know where he is?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: No. Schofield follows them, up a slope, and emerging out into  114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impromptu field station, where several overwhelmed MED OFFICERS, CHAPLAINS and ORDERLIES from the RAMC tend to t wounded. Schofield moves to the tent.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Sir, is Lieutenant Blake here?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: No idea. (beat) Move along Corporal. Schofield walks through the tent, scanning the wounded. Looking at the faces, the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFCIER
dialogues.text: If you can walk, move to the triage area. None of the men are officers, none could be Blake’s broth

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Blake! Blake?! Has anyone seen Lieutenant Blake? He moves through a tent of gravely wounded men. The terri sounds of the dying. None are Blake’s brother. Schofield moves outside. He finally stands still, hopeles Sick with his failure.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT, (0.S)
dialogues.text: Now come on boys. He’s taken one in the leg. He’s lost a lot of blood. Schofield turns to see an Officer. He is following a stretcher bearer into the field station from the opposite direction. Schofield stares at the man’s back. The sound of his voic Just an instinct...

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Blake? The Officer stops and turns to him. His similarity to his brother takes Schofield’s breath away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes. 115. Schofield is shaky on his feet. He sways a bit, staring a him.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you need medical assistance?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: No, Sir. I’m from the 8th.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I was sent here to deliver a message-— Recognition plays on Blake’s face, he smiles at the menti of his brother’s brigade, moves towards Schofield.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: The 8th? You must know my brother.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: I was sent here with him.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: Tom’s here? Where is he? Schofield looks at him. Blake’s smile slowly drops. A pau

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: It was very quick. Blake takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Blake nods, wordless. Schofield goes into his tunic pocke pulls out Blake’s possessions. There is blood on them. Th elder Blake’s face is ashen as he takes them. His eyes fi with tears

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: Schofield, Sir. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blake nods. He looks down at his brother’s possessions in hands.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... what?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: It’s Schofield, Sir. William Schofield. Will.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: Well, you need some food. Get yourself to the mess tent. Beat. Schofield turns to leave. Then -

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: If I may, I’d like to write to your mother. Tell her that Tom wasn’t alone.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: Of course. Schofield searches for something to say.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD
dialogues.text: He was...he was a good man. Always telling funny stories. Blake nods. It doesn’t seem enough. Then Schofield finds the right words.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOFIELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He saved my life. Schofield reaches out to shake his hand. Blake takes it. are still for a second.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT BLAKE
dialogues.text: I am glad you were with him. (Then) Thank you, Will. Schofield nods. He turns and walks away. He is like a sleepwalker. Unsure of where to go. He moves away from the makeshift Aid Post and into the me beyond. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grass sways in the breeze. This place is beginning turn gold in the morning sun. Schofield drifts through The noise of the horror behind him gradually fades. Ahead, on the plain, an oak tree towers. Untouched. On high branches, leaves dance in the wind. Schofield walks towards it. He sits on the far side of his back to the trunk. The land stretches out ahead of the early light. He listens to the wind in the leaves. Birdsong. 117. to it. the it, him in He undoes his breast pocket. He pulls out the small tobac tin. He stares at it. He takes a deep breath and opens it. Two photographs. Schofield lifts them out, looks at them: TWO YOUNG GIRLS, his daughters. They smile at the camera. He looks at the other - his WIFE. He turns the photo over. On the back, her handwriting: “Come back to us.” He stares at it for a long beat. The pain on his face ebbs into longing. Love. He closes his eyes and feels the sun on his face. THE END.

dialogues.speaker: FOR LANCE CORPORAL ALFRED H. MENDES
dialogues.text: 1ST BATTALION, KING’S ROYAL RIFLE CORPS
